text: Introduction
label: H4

text: Background
label: H4

text: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency’s (OCC) Comptroller’s Handbook booklet,
label: BODY

text: “Student Lending,” is prepared for use by OCC examiners in connection with their
label: BODY

text: examination and supervision of national banks and federal savings associations (collectively,
label: BODY

text: banks). Each bank is different and may present specific issues. Accordingly, examiners
label: BODY

text: should apply the information in this booklet consistent with each bank’s individual
label: BODY

text: circumstances. When it is necessary to distinguish between them, national banks and federal
label: BODY

text: savings associations (FSA) are referred to separately.
label: BODY

text: This booklet focuses on private student lending. Information regarding federal student loans
label: BODY

text: is included as industry background, for historical context, and to highlight differences
label: BODY

text: between federal student loans and private student loans. This booklet discusses how banks
label: BODY

text: may legally and prudently engage in private student lending and the risks inherent in such
label: BODY

text: lending; provides information on unique aspects of private student loans and industry
label: BODY

text: practices; and includes private student lending product information, the processes involved in
label: BODY

text: lending and risk management functions, and regulatory expectations for safe and sound
label: BODY

text: operations.
label: BODY

text: The booklet provides additional notes on guaranteed rehabilitated student loans, a pool of
label: BODY

text: loans that a small number of OCC-regulated community and midsize banks have shown
label: BODY

text: interest in and have added to their balance sheets.
label: BODY

text: Regulatory Considerations
label: BODY

text: The regulatory considerations for national banks and FSAs are discussed throughout this
label: BODY

text: booklet. One notable consideration for FSAs, which does not apply to national banks, is
label: BODY

text: section 5(c)(1)(U) of the Home Owners’ Loan Act.1 This statute allows FSAs to invest in,
label: BODY

text: sell, or otherwise deal in loans and other investments made for the payment of educational
label: BODY

text: expenses without any limit on the aggregate amount of such loans.
label: BODY

text: General Information
label: BODY

text: The student lending market began with the passage of the Higher Education Act of 1965
label: BODY

text: (HEA).2 This federal law governs the administration of federal student aid programs that
label: BODY

text: provide financial assistance to students in postsecondary and higher education. Title IV of the
label: BODY

text: HEA, which covers “financial assistance for students,” authorized the federal guaranteed
label: BODY

text: student loan program. The law was intended to strengthen the educational resources of
label: BODY

text: colleges and universities and to provide financial assistance for students in postsecondary and
label: BODY

text: 1 Refer to 12 USC 1464(c)(1)(U), “Federal Savings Associations: Loans or Investments Without Percentage of
label: BODY

text: Assets Limitation: Educational Loans,” and generally 12 USC 1461 et seq.
label: BODY

text: 2 Refer to Public Law 89-329, 79 Stat 1219 (1965) (codified as 20 USC 1000 et seq.).
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Background
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: higher education. Among other things, the HEA increased federal money given to
label: BODY

text: universities and awarded low-interest loans to students. Over the years, Congress has
label: BODY

text: periodically reauthorized the HEA and has amended programs, changed the language and
label: BODY

text: policies of existing programs, and established the statutory pricing of federal student loans.
label: BODY

text: The following are some of the federal student loan programs that have been available to
label: BODY

text: students and their parents to finance postsecondary education:
label: BODY

text: • William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program (Direct Loan Program):3 These loans
label: BODY

text: are made by the U.S. Department of Education rather than by private financial
label: BODY

text: institutions. The Direct Loan Program comprises four types of loans: Direct Subsidized
label: BODY

text: Stafford Loans,4 Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans, Direct Parental Loans for
label: BODY

text: Undergraduate Students (Direct PLUS Loans), and Direct Consolidation Loans
label: BODY

text: (consolidation loans). These loans are direct obligations of the Education Department, are
label: BODY

text: not underwritten, and have not been securitized.
label: BODY

text: • Federal Perkins Loan Program:5 These are low-interest, long-term loans intended for
label: BODY

text: undergraduate, graduate, and professional students with exceptional financial need. The
label: BODY

text: federal government subsidizes Perkins loans, meaning interest does not accrue until the
label: BODY

text: loan enters repayment. In the Federal Perkins Loan Program, federal funds are delivered
label: BODY

text: to the educational institution, which then becomes the lender. The borrower makes
label: BODY

text: payments to the educational institution or to the educational institution’s loan servicer.
label: BODY

text: • Federal Family Education Loan Program (FFELP):6 The passage of the Health Care
label: BODY

text: and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010 (HCERA) ended FFELP. While FFELP no
label: BODY

text: longer exists, banks that used to participate in FFELP may still be managing a runoff7
label: BODY

text: portfolio. These were loans funded by private banks and guaranteed by the federal
label: BODY

text: government through the Education Department. Through FFELP, the federal government
label: BODY

text: used to provide subsidies to private banks to offer federally insured loans that included
label: BODY

text: subsidized and unsubsidized Stafford Loans, Direct PLUS Loans, and consolidation
label: BODY

text: loans.
label: BODY

text: The federal government’s role in financing postsecondary and higher education has grown
label: BODY

text: significantly, and the government has now become the dominant source of financing.
label: BODY

text: 3 This is a student loan program authorized by Title IV, part C, of the HEA (20 USC 1087a et seq.). Refer to
label: BODY

text: 4 The interest on a Direct Subsidized Stafford Loan is paid for by the federal government while the student is in
label: BODY

text: school and during certain periods of deferment.
label: BODY

text: 5 This is a student loan program authorized by the HEA, Title IV, part D (20 USC 1087aa et seq.). Refer to
label: BODY

text: 34 CFR 673, “General Provisions for the Federal Perkins Loan Program, Federal Work-Study Program, and
label: BODY

text: Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant Program.” Also refer to 34 CFR 674, “Federal Perkins
label: BODY

text: Loan Program.”
label: BODY

text: 6 This is a student loan program formerly authorized by Title IV, part B, of the HEA (20 USC 1071 et seq.).
label: BODY

text: Refer to 34 CFR 682, “Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program.”
label: BODY

text: 7 The term “runoff” is defined as reduction of a loan portfolio as loans are paid off at scheduled maturity dates
label: BODY

text: while no new business is being booked.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Background
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Alternative loans or private student loans are loans offered through lending programs funded
label: BODY

text: by private lending institutions. By offering private student loans, banks generally provide a
label: BODY

text: supplement to the federal government in financing postsecondary and higher education, e.g.,
label: BODY

text: when the maximum federal student loan available to a student is less than the cost of
label: BODY

text: attending a school.
label: BODY

text: Business Model
label: BODY

text: Private student loans are consumer loans offered to borrowers to fund undergraduate,
label: BODY

text: graduate, and other forms of postsecondary education. Under Regulation Z
label: BODY

text: (12 CFR 1026.46(b)(5)), a private education loan means an extension of credit that
label: BODY

text: • is not made, insured, or guaranteed under Title IV of the HEA (20 USC 1070 et seq.).
label: BODY

text: • is extended to a consumer expressly, in whole or in part, for postsecondary educational
label: BODY

text: expenses, regardless of whether the loan is provided by the educational institution that the
label: BODY

text: student attends.
label: BODY

text: • does not include open-end credit or any loan that is secured by real property or a
label: BODY

text: dwelling.
label: BODY

text: • does not include an extension of credit in which the covered educational institution is the
label: BODY

text: creditor if
label: BODY

text: – the term of the extension of credit is 90 days or less; or
label: BODY

text: – an interest rate will not be applied to the credit balance and the term of the extension
label: BODY

text: of credit is one year or less, even if the credit is payable in more than four
label: BODY

text: installments.
label: BODY

text: Before the financial crisis began in 2008 and before FFELP was discontinued, some lenders
label: BODY

text: operated on an integrated business model that included both federal guaranteed and private
label: BODY

text: student loans. Banks held legal title to FFELP loans and received claim payments from
label: BODY

text: eligible guarantors if eligible borrowers defaulted. FFELP loans generated income for banks
label: BODY

text: in the form of interest income, interest subsidy payments,8 default reimbursement, and
label: BODY

text: special allowance payments.9 Interest subsidy payments were paid while the students were in
label: BODY

text: school, during the grace period, and during certain periods of deferment. FFELP loans
label: BODY

text: received a 97 percent to 100 percent guarantee of principal and accrued interest, with
label: BODY

text: reimbursement contingent on following the Education Department’s servicing guidelines and
label: BODY

text: due diligence requirements.10
label: BODY

text: 8 Interest subsidy payments are in-school interest payments on certain subsidized student loans paid for by the
label: BODY

text: Education Department.
label: BODY

text: 9 Special allowance payments were subsidies from the Education Department to FFELP lenders to ensure that
label: BODY

text: lenders received a minimum rate of return. Special allowance payments acted as an incentive for lenders to
label: BODY

text: make education loans by, in effect, making up the difference between the interest rate charged to a FFELP
label: BODY

text: borrower and market interest rates.
label: BODY

text: 10 Refer to Common Manual: Unified Student Loan Policy, chapters 10 and 12. This resource is a cooperative
label: BODY

text: effort of all the nation’s guarantors that participate in FFELP.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Background
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: The financial crisis altered the banking landscape dramatically, resulting in fewer bank
label: BODY

text: participants in postsecondary education lending and changes in banks’ strategies. Banks had
label: BODY

text: to reassess the long-term risk and return aspects of the private student loan business and
label: BODY

text: make conscious decisions regarding the level and extent of their involvement in
label: BODY

text: postsecondary education lending. Several large banks either withdrew or scaled back their
label: BODY

text: private student loan offerings. Community banks, too, have been affected, and in many cases
label: BODY

text: found it difficult to compete with the product array and pricing offered by larger institutions
label: BODY

text: and the federal government. There are very few banks still engaged in private student
label: BODY

text: lending, and those banks generally keep their portfolio exposures to a minimum. Today, the
label: BODY

text: overall size of the private student loan portfolio is considered small compared with the
label: BODY

text: overall size of the federal student loan portfolio. A small number of community banks,
label: BODY

text: however, found an emerging opportunity in the federal guaranteed rehabilitated student loan
label: BODY

text: program.11
label: BODY

text: The disruption in the securitization market during the financial crisis forced banks to alter
label: BODY

text: their strategies. Banks that were originating and selling both FFELP and private student loans
label: BODY

text: as asset-backed securities in the secondary market were forced to keep them in bank
label: BODY

text: portfolios.
label: BODY

text: Most significantly, when the HCERA eliminated FFELP, the role of banks in federal student
label: BODY

text: lending was discontinued for new loans. On July 1, 2010, the Direct Loan Program replaced
label: BODY

text: FFELP12 and it has been the only source of new federal student loans since then. These loans
label: BODY

text: are obtained through the educational institution’s financial aid office with funds provided by
label: BODY

text: the Education Department. The terms and features of the federal student loans under the
label: BODY

text: Direct Loan Program are similar to the terms and features of the federal student loans
label: BODY

text: previously available through FFELP.
label: BODY

text: Although FFELP has been eliminated, banks continue to own and service loans made under
label: BODY

text: FFELP. Because of their long repayment terms (120 to 360 months), runoff FFELP loans
label: BODY

text: remain in the banks’ portfolios. It is not unusual for examiners to find banks with both
label: BODY

text: private student loan and federal guaranteed student loan exposures on their balance sheets.
label: BODY

text: Private student loans supplement federal student loans when federal student loans and other
label: BODY

text: financial aid are not sufficient to cover the entire cost of education. Borrowers attending
label: BODY

text: high-cost institutions or pursuing advanced degrees may turn to private student loan
label: BODY

text: programs for additional financing. Banks should strongly encourage their borrowers to
label: BODY

text: exhaust scholarships, grants, other financial aid, and federal student loans before applying for
label: BODY

text: private student loans.
label: BODY

text: Student loan growth is not normally tied to the same factors that drive consumer lending,
label: BODY

text: such as economic cyclicality, housing prices, and disposable income. In fact, student lending
label: BODY

text: 11 Refer to the “Rehabilitated Federal Student Loans” section of this booklet for a discussion of the Federal
label: BODY

text: Rehabilitation Student Loan Program.
label: BODY

text: 12 FFELP’s elimination only prohibited the making of new FFELP loans. If the first disbursement of a FFELP
label: BODY

text: loan occurred before July 1, 2010, further disbursements of that loan could continue under FFELP.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Background
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: exhibits some counter-cyclicality. A poor job market often encourages student borrowing
label: BODY

text: because securing a college degree can improve job prospects. Some students may stay in
label: BODY

text: school to avoid competing in a poor job market.
label: BODY

text: There is heightened public awareness and public policy attention centered on all participants
label: BODY

text: in student lending. Banks should be mindful of the unique aspects of student lending, such as
label: BODY

text: the significant time lag between loan advances and repayment, and the student borrower’s
label: BODY

text: lack of certainty in finding a stable, reliable primary source of repayment after graduation.
label: BODY

text: Banks should pursue student lending in a measured and deliberate way. If managed and
label: BODY

text: administered in an appropriate manner, student lending could benefit banks by providing
label: BODY

text: them with a wider array of consumer products and a more diverse business model, and
label: BODY

text: helping them reach new customers.
label: BODY

text: Private Student Loan Features
label: BODY

text: Most retail loan products are straightforward in terms of underwriting, loan structure, and
label: BODY

text: account management. The use of funds is for a specific purpose, and the source of repayment
label: BODY

text: is well-defined, well-structured, and typically verified as reliable at origination. Private
label: BODY

text: student loans are less straightforward and require lenders to adapt loan structures and
label: BODY

text: repayment terms to product characteristics.
label: BODY

text: Private student loans fund postsecondary education, are geared to the educational purpose of
label: BODY

text: the loans and borrower needs, and require a substantial, long-term commitment. These loans
label: BODY

text: lack collateral, and there is a significant time lag between loan advances and stable, reliable
label: BODY

text: primary sources of repayment. This last factor is particularly important and often leads to
label: BODY

text: differences in underwriting, loan repayment structures, and borrower assistance during
label: BODY

text: repayment. Private student loans generally are not dischargeable in bankruptcy.13
label: BODY

text: Student loan repayment structures (federal and private) generally provide in-school
label: BODY

text: deferment and post-school grace periods that help borrowers transition from in-school status
label: BODY

text: to full-time employment. Student loans generally are the only consumer product with such a
label: BODY

text: transition.
label: BODY

text: Banks that offer private student loans generally require borrower enrollment in degree-
label: BODY

text: seeking programs. Private student loan features vary by target market and finance different
label: BODY

text: education programs, including undergraduate, law, and business; medical, dental, and other
label: BODY

text: health-related education; and general graduate studies, parent loans for students pursuing
label: BODY

text: these programs, and loans to borrowers attending career schools and community colleges.
label: BODY

text: Banks offer private student loans to specifically cover costs of medical boards and clinical
label: BODY

text: exams, medical residency interview and relocation, internships, and costs associated with
label: BODY

text: studying for a bar exam for law graduates. Some banks offer consolidation loans to simplify
label: BODY

text: and streamline borrower repayment into a single payment and billing due date.
label: BODY

text: 13 Refer to 11 USC 523(a)(8), “Exceptions to Discharge.” Private student loans generally are not dischargeable
label: BODY

text: in bankruptcy if they are originated for borrowers attending schools eligible to participate in federal student loan
label: BODY

text: programs. Private student loans extended to students in programs without access to federal funding (i.e., certain
label: BODY

text: trade schools) may be dischargeable in bankruptcy.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Background
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Examiners should consider whether banks are appropriately setting the product requirements,
label: BODY

text: term, pricing, and loan limits, and whether these features meet borrower needs and
label: BODY

text: circumstances. Additionally, policies and procedures should provide adequate guidance to
label: BODY

text: ensure that loans offered to borrowers are consistent with their needs, objectives, and
label: BODY

text: financial conditions.
label: BODY

text: Federal Student Loans Versus Private Student Loans
label: BODY

text: Examiners should consider the unique aspects of student loans and understand that there are
label: BODY

text: significant differences and relative similarities between federal student loan programs
label: BODY

text: (FFELP and Direct Loan) and private student loans.
label: BODY

text: Differences
label: BODY

text: • Loss guarantees: FFELP loans received loss guarantees of 97 percent to 100 percent
label: BODY

text: depending on origination dates. FFELP loans originated before October 1993 received a
label: BODY

text: 100 percent guarantee; loans originated between October 1993 and June 2006 received a
label: BODY

text: 98 percent guarantee; and loans originated on or after July 1, 2006, received a 97 percent
label: BODY

text: guarantee. In contrast, private student loans do not carry any such federal government
label: BODY

text: guarantee. To mitigate private student loan losses, some banks purchased loan loss
label: BODY

text: insurance from third-party insurers. The disruption in the insurance market in 2008 ended
label: BODY

text: this practice.
label: BODY

text: • Application: A borrower must complete and file the Free Application for Federal
label: BODY

text: Student Aid (FAFSA) form with the educational institution’s financial aid office to apply
label: BODY

text: for a federal student loan. No FAFSA form is required to apply for a private student loan.
label: BODY

text: • Pricing and loan amount: Interest rates and loan borrowing limits on federal student
label: BODY

text: loans are set by statute for all eligible borrowers under a particular loan program.14
label: BODY

text: Private student loan interest rates and loan amounts are risk-based.
label: BODY

text: • Criteria: The borrower eligibility criteria for federal student loans allow most borrowers
label: BODY

text: to qualify. Federal eligibility criteria rely on federal needs analysis methodology and do
label: BODY

text: not, in most cases, employ credit checks, with the exception of PLUS loans.15 Private
label: BODY

text: student loans are underwritten based on a set of risk-based, lender-developed credit
label: BODY

text: criteria that consider the borrower’s credit history and ability to repay, and often require a
label: BODY

text: cosigner(s).
label: BODY

text: 14 20 USC 1087e(b)(8), “Terms and Conditions of Loans: Interest Rate Provisions for New Loans On or After
label: BODY

text: July 1, 2013,” establishes the current interest rates for direct loans. 20 USC 1077a, “Applicable Interest Rates,”
label: BODY

text: established maximum interest rates for federal guaranteed loans made under FFELP, including Direct PLUS
label: BODY

text: Loans.
label: BODY

text: 15 Under 20 USC 1087kk et seq., the term “needs analysis” is defined as a standardized assessment of a
label: BODY

text: student’s or a student’s family’s ability to contribute toward educational expenses.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Background
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: • Default: The Education Department defines a default on a federal student loan as
label: BODY

text: occurring after 270 days of nonpayment.16 A private student loan is in default after
label: BODY

text: 120 days of nonpayment.17
label: BODY

text: • Workout program: Any workout program offered by banks to financially distressed
label: BODY

text: private borrowers should follow existing banking guidance, and adhere to generally
label: BODY

text: accepted accounting principles (GAAP) in determining if the loan constitutes a troubled
label: BODY

text: debt restructuring (TDR). Federal student loan statutes do not have the same
label: BODY

text: requirements.
label: BODY

text: • Collection tools:
label: BODY

text: – A lawsuit is the main tool available to banks to pursue collection of defaulted private
label: BODY

text: student loans. In contrast, defaulted federal student loans can be pursued using
label: BODY

text: additional tools outside of court, including seizure of tax refunds, garnishment of
label: BODY

text: wages without a court order, denial of other financial student aid and grants, taking a
label: BODY

text: portion of Social Security benefits received, and revocation of professional or
label: BODY

text: vocational licenses.
label: BODY

text: – Depending on the state, banks may have to consider the applicable statute of
label: BODY

text: limitations to enforce private student loan court judgments. Some states allow banks
label: BODY

text: to continuously renew the judgments to prevent them from being subjected to statute
label: BODY

text: of limitations. In comparison, there are no statutes of limitations for collection on
label: BODY

text: federal student loans.18
label: BODY

text: Similarities
label: BODY

text: • Academic year basis: Both federal and private student loan programs generally grant or
label: BODY

text: separately approve loans for each academic year.19
label: BODY

text: • In-school deferment and grace period: Both federal and private student loan programs
label: BODY

text: generally allow the deferment of payments while borrowers are attending school at least
label: BODY

text: 16 For federal student loans, default is the failure of a borrower (or endorser or co-maker, if any) to make
label: BODY

text: installment payments when due, if this failure persists for the most recent period of 270 days (for a loan
label: BODY

text: repayable in monthly installments) or the most recent 330-day period (for a loan repayable in less frequent
label: BODY

text: installments). Refer to Common Manual: Unified Student Loan Policy, “Appendix G: Glossary.”
label: BODY

text: 17 Refer to OCC Bulletin 2000-20, “Uniform Retail Credit Classification and Account Management Policy:
label: BODY

text: Policy Implementation.”
label: BODY

text: 18 Section 484A(a) of the HEA provides that no statute of limitations bars enforcement action to collect federal
label: BODY

text: student loans, including collection by offset, lawsuit, or enforcement on student loan judgments.
label: BODY

text: 20 USC 1091a(a), “Statute of Limitations, and State Court Judgments,” states that state law that would
label: BODY

text: otherwise limit these actions is superseded by federal law and cannot bar collection action.
label: BODY

text: 19 The Education Department uses the academic year for determining a borrower’s Title IV aid eligibility. The
label: BODY

text: term “academic year” is defined as a period during which an undergraduate, full-time student is expected to
label: BODY

text: complete either of the following: (1) at least 30 weeks of instructional time and 24 semester or trimester hours,
label: BODY

text: or 36 quarter hours in an educational program that measures program length in credit hours, or (2) at least 26
label: BODY

text: weeks of instructional time and 900 clock hours in an educational program that measures program length in
label: BODY

text: clock hours. Refer to Common Manual: Unified Student Loan Policy, “Appendix G: Glossary.”
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risks Associated With Private Student Lending
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: • half time. Both types of programs generally provide for a six-month grace period after
label: BODY

text: graduation or separation from school before repayment begins.
label: BODY

text: • Bankruptcy: Both private and federal student loans generally are not dischargeable in
label: BODY

text: bankruptcy unless borrowers can establish that repaying the loans would cause “undue
label: BODY

text: hardship.”20
label: BODY

text: Risks Associated With Private Student Lending
label: BODY

text: From a supervisory perspective, risk is the potential that events will have an adverse effect on
label: BODY

text: a bank’s current or projected financial condition21 and resilience.22 The OCC has defined
label: BODY

text: eight categories of risk for bank supervision purposes: credit, interest rate, liquidity, price,
label: BODY

text: operational, compliance, strategic, and reputation. These categories are not mutually
label: BODY

text: exclusive. Any product or service may expose a bank to multiple risks. Risks also may be
label: BODY

text: interdependent and may be positively or negatively correlated. Examiners should be aware of
label: BODY

text: this interdependence and assess the effect in a consistent and inclusive manner. Examiners
label: BODY

text: also should be alert to concentrations that can significantly elevate risk. Concentrations can
label: BODY

text: accumulate within and across products, business lines, geographic areas, countries, and legal
label: BODY

text: entities. Refer to the “Bank Supervision Process” booklet of the Comptroller’s Handbook for
label: BODY

text: an expanded discussion of banking risks and their definitions.
label: BODY

text: The risks associated with private student lending are credit, operational, compliance,
label: BODY

text: liquidity, strategic, reputation, and interest rate.
label: BODY

text: Credit Risk
label: BODY

text: Credit risk is the most significant risk in private student lending. Private student loans are
label: BODY

text: atypical of consumer loans because banks generally rely on the student borrower’s
label: BODY

text: prospective ability to repay. Private student loans finance a postsecondary education that
label: BODY

text: often requires a considerable loan amount and a long-term bank commitment. These loans
label: BODY

text: lack collateral, and there usually is a significant time lag between loan advances and the start
label: BODY

text: of repayment. Borrowers are expected to graduate and generate a stable, reliable primary
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Consumer attitudes toward debt, affordability of higher education, underwriting standards,
label: BODY

text: federal education policy, government public interests, and risk layering all can affect credit
label: BODY

text: risk in private student loans. The effects of these factors are more pronounced for banks that
label: BODY

text: lend to higher-risk borrowers with limited credit history and no direct source of repayment.
label: BODY

text: In addition, private student loans can have elevated credit risk due to their variable rate
label: BODY

text: feature and extended repayment terms. An unreasonable repayment period without
label: BODY

text: consideration of the loan size may contribute to credit risk. Borrowers and cosigners who use
label: BODY

text: deferment to delay loan repayment could pose increased credit risk to the bank. While in
label: BODY

text: deferment, the loan amount continues to increase because of capitalized interest and may
label: BODY

text: mean higher cost to borrowers.
label: BODY

text: Concentration risk is related to and affects credit risk. Concentration risk in private student
label: BODY

text: lending can result from originating a large volume of loans to a specific class of borrowers,
label: BODY

text: product type, and educational institution, or to borrowers affected by common economic
label: BODY

text: events. Credit risk exists throughout the lending cycles of private student loans. These cycles
label: BODY

text: include acquisition, initial underwriting, account management, and collection. Similar to
label: BODY

text: other consumer loans, private student lending involves grouping homogeneous loans when
label: BODY

text: credit risk is evaluated and managed on a segment or pooled basis.
label: BODY

text: Credit risk can be reduced in several ways. Banks should have a rigorous process of
label: BODY

text: assessing their risk appetite, establishing product concentration limits measured as a
label: BODY

text: percentage of capital, and charting forward-looking business strategies. Banks can control
label: BODY

text: their credit risks by having strong credit risk management processes to guard against the
label: BODY

text: unexpected and to measure, monitor, and control risks. Banks should have clearly
label: BODY

text: documented and updated policies and procedures, underwriting standards, effective
label: BODY

text: collection programs, and good management information systems (MIS).
label: BODY

text: Examiners assess credit risk in private student lending by evaluating portfolio performance,
label: BODY

text: profitability, borrower profiles, products, and markets. Examiners should consider changes in
label: BODY

text: underwriting standards, account acquisition channels, the credit score system used by the
label: BODY

text: bank, and its marketing strategy.
label: BODY

text: Operational Risk
label: BODY

text: Similar to other retail loan products, student loan credit operations are primarily process-
label: BODY

text: based and rely extensively on technology and automation along with ongoing innovation. For
label: BODY

text: example, most banks have an application processing system (auto-decision system) that is
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: enrollment. The COA estimate should include tuition and fees, room and board, books and supplies,
label: BODY

text: transportation, and personal expenses. COA is used solely for determining financial aid. The COA should
label: BODY

text: include only those costs already incurred, or expected to be incurred, by the student over the course of the loan
label: BODY

text: period. COA may not include outstanding charges or fees from a previous period of enrollment.

text: programmed to streamline the student loan decision process. The process systematically
label: BODY

text: approves applicants who meet preapproved requirements. Banks employ credit scoring24
label: BODY

text: technology. Because the operations tend to be so highly automated, banks should manage the
label: BODY

text: processes prudently and maintain the systems and controls necessary to effectively identify,
label: BODY

text: measure, monitor, and control operational risk.
label: BODY

text: Almost all banks engaged in student lending use third parties to perform various operational
label: BODY

text: functions, such as loan acquisition and origination, servicing, and collections. Increased due
label: BODY

text: diligence is required in these situations to minimize operational risk. Outsourcing specific
label: BODY

text: activities may provide enhanced profitability; the risk, however, remains with the banks.
label: BODY

text: OCC Bulletin 2013-29, “Third-Party Relationships: Risk Management Guidance,” sets forth
label: BODY

text: supervisory expectations in this area for banks.
label: BODY

text: Fraud is another operational risk present in private student lending. Banks should guard
label: BODY

text: against private student loan fraud by verifying that funds are used to pay borrowers’ tuition
label: BODY

text: and other education expenses. Operating through the school channel versus a direct-to-
label: BODY

text: consumer channel allows for such verification.
label: BODY

text: Examiners assess operational risk by evaluating the adequacy of private student loan
label: BODY

text: application, processing, loan servicing, and collections systems and controls. Examiners
label: BODY

text: should consider the volume of accounts managed, the capabilities of systems and
label: BODY

text: technologies in relation to current and prospective volume, contingency preparedness, and
label: BODY

text: exposures throughout the servicing system.
label: BODY

text: Compliance Risk
label: BODY

text: A significant number of consumer-related laws and regulations affect private student lending
label: BODY

text: and make this type of lending vulnerable to compliance risk. The origination and collection
label: BODY

text: of private student loans are subject to federal and state consumer protection laws and
label: BODY

text: regulations. Banks’ failure to comply with such laws and regulations could result in the
label: BODY

text: assessment of fees, penalties, and adverse ratings. The following is a list of some of the
label: BODY

text: consumer-related laws and regulations25 applicable to private student lending:
label: BODY

text: • The Truth in Lending Act of 1968 (TILA), as implemented by Regulation Z
label: BODY

text: (12 CFR 1026), and amended by the Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2008, which
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: or 90+ days past due.) The scores generated indicate the relative level of risk in either ascending or descending
label: BODY

text: order, depending on the convention used by the model developer. Credit scoring also is used to control risk in
label: BODY

text: acquisition and underwriting, account management, and collection processes.

text: Liquidity Risk
label: BODY

text: Banks engaged in private student lending generally fund their portfolios either through asset-
label: BODY

text: backed securitization or by leveraging the banks’ deposit base, or a combination of the two.
label: BODY

text: Banks are exposed to liquidity risk when student loans are not in active repayment. Most
label: BODY

text: private student loan programs allow students who are in school or in grace, deferment, or
label: BODY

text: forbearance periods to defer payment of principal or interest or both. These loans not in
label: BODY

text: active repayment status do not generate cash flow. The time lag for loans in deferment and
label: BODY

text: forbearance presents additional liquidity risk to banks in the form of increased durations of
label: BODY

text: loans and possible increased default frequency.
label: BODY

text: For banks with off-balance-sheet private student loan exposures, interest and principal on
label: BODY

text: bonds backed by such collateral may still be due during periods of reduced cash flow. To
label: BODY

text: avoid shortfalls in available funds to make such payments, banks often include capitalized
label: BODY

text: interest accounts to cover the amount of reduced cash flow expected on the specific portfolio.
label: BODY

text: Liquidity risk is present if banks securitize their private student loan portfolios. Underwriting
label: BODY

text: standards and administrative policies and procedures may not meet market requirements or
label: BODY

text: expectations. Such an event may increase costs or limit access to funding markets in the
label: BODY

text: future. Portfolio composition and portfolio volatility affect the salability of portfolios to
label: BODY

text: investors and for securitization. Examiners should refer to the “Asset Securitization” booklet
label: BODY

text: of the Comptroller’s Handbook for more information on securitization and on how to
label: BODY

text: examine these activities.
label: BODY

text: Strategic Risk
label: BODY

text: Banks offering private student loans should understand and evaluate competition, market
label: BODY

text: conditions, borrower behavior, and economic, regulatory, and environmental factors that
label: BODY

text: affect the industry. When making any changes to strategic direction, such as offering new

text: student loan products, altering pricing strategies, expanding product features, or encouraging

text: growth, banks should consider relevant factors. Banks’ decision to enter, exit, or otherwise
label: BODY

text: change their participation in the market should have a sound basis rooted in thorough
label: BODY

text: evaluation of all available information and due diligence.36 Banks should realistically assess
label: BODY

text: the risk involved in such decisions and evaluate whether these decisions are consistent with
label: BODY

text: their management expertise, operating capacity, and resources, and align with their risk
label: BODY

text: appetite and capital adequacy. The failure to properly assess these factors may expose banks
label: BODY

text: to unnecessary and unanticipated strategic risk and financial loss.

text: Reputation Risk
label: BODY

text: Customer dissatisfaction due to operational breakdowns, general weaknesses in any aspect of
label: BODY

text: the private student lending program, and inadequate policies and procedures can harm banks’
label: BODY

text: reputation. Reputation risk can escalate if borrowers perceive that lending practices are
label: BODY

text: unfair, deceptive, abusive, or predatory. Delegation of bank functions to third parties
label: BODY

text: heightens reputation risk.
label: BODY

text: Technological and news media developments have made reputation risk more consequential
label: BODY

text: than ever before for banks engaged in private student lending. Poor servicing of existing
label: BODY

text: accounts or non-resolution of borrower issues can generate immediate headlines and negative
label: BODY

text: publicity for banks. The 2008 financial crisis brought attention to the large amount of overall
label: BODY

text: student debt (both federal and private). For many higher education stakeholders, it has been
label: BODY

text: difficult to differentiate between bank and nonbank private student loan lenders. During the
label: BODY

text: economic downturn, high unemployment along with increased student loan default (federal
label: BODY

text: and private) exposed banks to negative headlines concerning private student loans. Private
label: BODY

text: student loan portfolios may be small in scale and not material to the banks’ overall business,
label: BODY

text: but the reputation risk could be significant.
label: BODY

text: Appropriate systems and controls to identify, measure, monitor, and control reputation risk
label: BODY

text: are critical to a bank’s risk management.
label: BODY

text: Interest Rate Risk
label: BODY

text: Most private student loans have a variable rate feature that is sensitive to yield curve risk.
label: BODY

text: Any shifts in the yield curve or flattening of the yield curve can have an adverse impact on
label: BODY

text: the portfolio. Deferring payments while borrowers are in school at least half time is a
label: BODY

text: common practice in private student lending. This unique characteristic of private student
label: BODY

text: lending could make banks vulnerable to additional interest rate risk because of timing of cash
label: BODY

text: flows and changes in both cash flow and earnings spread.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Each bank should identify, measure, monitor, and control risk by implementing an effective
label: BODY

text: risk management system appropriate for the size and complexity of its operations. When
label: BODY

text: examiners assess the effectiveness of a bank’s risk management system, they consider the
label: BODY

text: bank’s policies, processes, personnel, and control systems. Refer to the “Bank Supervision
label: BODY

text: Process” booklet of the Comptroller’s Handbook for an expanded discussion of risk
label: BODY

text: management.
label: BODY

text: Marketing and Account Acquisition
label: BODY

text: Private student loan originations may rely on multiple marketing channels. These channels
label: BODY

text: may include bank branches, direct mail, school referral, and online or Internet sourcing.
label: BODY

text: For the school referral channel, banks may employ sales forces that establish relationships
label: BODY

text: with school financial aid offices as preferred lenders.37 Banks target students at schools with
label: BODY

text: applications generally submitted online. Banks use direct-to-consumer marketing and online
label: BODY

text: channels to target borrowers and reach broader footprints. The most common method of
label: BODY

text: application is through secure websites operated directly by banks or third parties. Banks use
label: BODY

text: direct mail and sales staff focused on targeted schools.
label: BODY

text: Before the financial crisis, contractual relationships existed between banks and guaranty
label: BODY

text: agencies that originated (underwrote), guaranteed, disbursed, and serviced private student
label: BODY

text: loans on behalf of banks. Very few of these relationships survived the financial crisis.
label: BODY

text: Whatever channels banks employ to originate private student loans, banks should have the
label: BODY

text: systems to monitor the performance of those channels and control any risks. Failure to
label: BODY

text: implement strong control environments can lead to such problems as fraud, compliance
label: BODY

text: issues, or a host of situations with unexpected consequences.
label: BODY

text: Banks that originate private student loans are bound by TILA requirements. The general rules
label: BODY

text: applicable to the special disclosure requirements for private education loans are detailed in

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: disclosure requirements as well as final disclosure requirements under section
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: OCC Bulletin 2013-29, “Third-Party Relationships: Risk Management Guidance.” Banks’

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: the borrowers’ future income. Despite their unique purpose and nature, private student loans
label: BODY

text: are unsecured retail credit products, and banks should adhere to safe and sound credit
label: BODY

text: underwriting and documentation standards as stated in 12 CFR 30, appendix A, “Safety and
label: BODY

text: Soundness Standards,” that include the following:
label: BODY

text: Prudent credit underwriting practices that
label: BODY

text: • are commensurate with the types of loans banks will make and that consider the terms
label: BODY

text: and conditions under which the loans will be made.
label: BODY

text: • consider the nature of the markets in which loans will be made.
label: BODY

text: • provide for consideration, before credit commitment, of borrowers’ overall financial
label: BODY

text: condition and resources, the financial responsibility of any guarantors, the nature and
label: BODY

text: value of any underlying collateral, and borrowers’ character and willingness to repay as
label: BODY

text: agreed.
label: BODY

text: • establish a system of independent, ongoing credit review and appropriate communication
label: BODY

text: to management and to the board of directors.
label: BODY

text: • take adequate account of capital planning consistent with strategic planning and
label: BODY

text: associated concentration of credit risk.
label: BODY

text: • are appropriate to the banks’ size and the nature and scope of the banks’ activities.
label: BODY

text: Loan documentation practices that
label: BODY

text: • enable the banks to make informed lending decisions and to assess risk, as necessary, on
label: BODY

text: an ongoing basis.
label: BODY

text: • identify the loans’ purpose and sources of repayment and assess the borrowers’ ability to
label: BODY

text: repay the indebtedness in a timely manner.
label: BODY

text: • ensure that any claim against borrowers is legally enforceable.
label: BODY

text: • demonstrate appropriate administration and monitoring of loans.
label: BODY

text: • take account of the loans’ size and complexity.
label: BODY

text: Private student loans vary significantly in terms of underwriting, pricing, maximum loan
label: BODY

text: amounts, and repayment terms. Underwriting and product terms should appropriately
label: BODY

text: recognize the risks of unsecured lending to a higher-risk borrower population (by virtue of
label: BODY

text: unproven credit records). The ability of students to achieve gainful employment after
label: BODY

text: graduation is one of the determinants of default frequency.
label: BODY

text: Private student loans should be carefully underwritten to minimize the occurrence of default
label: BODY

text: or the need to provide repayment assistance. Banks should have adequate and sound credit
label: BODY

text: policies and procedures that focus on the main criteria for decision-making and verification
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: processes. The following are some of the underwriting factors and requirements that banks
label: BODY

text: have used in private student lending:41
label: BODY

text: • Educational institution and education program
label: BODY

text: • Borrower and cosigner creditworthiness
label: BODY

text: • Maximum student debt per academic year and cost of attendance (COA)
label: BODY

text: • Marketing channel
label: BODY

text: • Credit bureau risk score
label: BODY

text: • Credit history
label: BODY

text: • Minimum gross income
label: BODY

text: • Income verification
label: BODY

text: • Loan features and structure
label: BODY

text: • Citizenship status and U.S. residency
label: BODY

text: Educational Institutions
label: BODY

text: Some private student lenders use factors relating to the educational institutions that
label: BODY

text: borrowers attend for determining underwriting and pricing of private student loans.42 Banks
label: BODY

text: have considered
label: BODY

text: • educational institutions’ financial history, accreditation, financial stability, and long-term
label: BODY

text: viability.
label: BODY

text: • the average time and cost to complete degrees or programs.
label: BODY

text: • the average dropout, graduation, and completion rates.
label: BODY

text: • employment rates and average salaries for graduates and, if available, for dropouts.
label: BODY

text: • banks’ own default rate experience regarding the educational institutions’ borrowers who
label: BODY

text: recently entered repayment.
label: BODY

text: When banks target borrowers enrolled at particular institutions or in specific education
label: BODY

text: programs, comprehensive and effective due diligence is critical to understanding the level of
label: BODY

text: risk assumed. Banks should update and review this information regularly, or at least
label: BODY

text: annually, and perform the due diligence as long as the relationships with particular
label: BODY

text: educational institutions continue.
label: BODY

text: Some banks consider lending only to borrowers attending educational institutions that pass
label: BODY

text: the Education Department’s eligibility criteria. School eligibility is defined by the Education
label: BODY

text: Department as those institutions qualified to participate in Title IV of the HEA, and one of
label: BODY

text: the required conditions for a school to qualify is to have an acceptable cohort default rate
label: BODY

text: 41 Banks using factors that may not be related to loan terms or borrower creditworthiness, such as the
label: BODY

text: educational institution or citizenship status, should closely consider and monitor the fair lending implications of
label: BODY

text: these factors. Refer to the “Educational Institutions” section of this booklet.
label: BODY

text: 42 Refer to GAO-10-86R, “Higher Education: Factors Lenders Consider in Making Lending Decisions for
label: BODY

text: Private Education Loans,” November 17, 2009.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: (CDR) on federal student loans.43 CDR consideration in private lending for school eligibility,
label: BODY

text: underwriting, or pricing may have a disproportionate negative impact on minority students
label: BODY

text: who disproportionately attend schools with higher CDRs.44 Banks should carefully analyze
label: BODY

text: the potential fair lending implications of using CDR and other non-individual factors and
label: BODY

text: document the legitimate business need for their use.
label: BODY

text: Another criterion that banks generally consider is the type of educational institution. The
label: BODY

text: Education Department defines three types of eligible institutions of higher education: public
label: BODY

text: or private nonprofit institutions, proprietary institutions (private and for-profit), and public or
label: BODY

text: private nonprofit postsecondary vocational institutions defined in 34 CFR 600.4,
label: BODY

text: 34 CFR 600.5, 34 CFR 600.6, and 34 CFR 600.9. Banks that extend loans to borrowers who
label: BODY

text: attend nontraditional education programs or alternative programs should take into
label: BODY

text: consideration that certain trade schools or vocational institutions may not have access to
label: BODY

text: federal funding under Title IV. Therefore, private student loans extended to finance
label: BODY

text: attendance in these institutions may be dischargeable in bankruptcy.
label: BODY

text: To manage risk, banks should track loan performance and report on established concentration
label: BODY

text: limits for each student loan program, geographic area, school type (graduate program, four-
label: BODY

text: or two-year institution, or trade school), origination channel (e.g., school or online), and loan
label: BODY

text: quality or risk grade.
label: BODY

text: Borrower Creditworthiness
label: BODY

text: Banks should have underwriting criteria designed to measure the borrowers’ financial
label: BODY

text: capacity, in terms of disposable income available for orderly debt repayment, and willingness
label: BODY

text: to repay, typically based on past performance on financial obligations. Because there is no
label: BODY

text: reliable method for considering future income or other future events in the underwriting
label: BODY

text: process of private student loans, banks typically require cosigners on loans. This allows for
label: BODY

text: additional borrower support if borrowers are unable to make loan payments after graduation
label: BODY

text: or program completion.
label: BODY

text: A cosigner is any person who assumes personal liability, in any capacity, for the obligation
label: BODY

text: of a borrower without receiving goods, services, or money in return for the obligation. The
label: BODY

text: cosigner is equally and severally liable and is expected to make payments on the primary
label: BODY

text: borrower’s debt should that borrower default. Having a cosigner is a way for a private
label: BODY

text: student loan borrower with a low income or poor or limited credit history to qualify for and
label: BODY

text: obtain more favorable financing terms.
label: BODY

text: Most banks offer cosigners a release option after the initial 36 to 48 consecutive, on-time
label: BODY

text: payments of principal and interest after repayment begins, subject to verification of the
label: BODY

text: primary borrower’s continuous ability to repay. Most banks offer cosigner release in the
label: BODY

text: unfortunate event of the student borrower’s death or total and permanent disability. Banks
label: BODY

text: 43 Refer to 34 CFR 668.206, “Consequences of Cohort Default Rates on Your Ability to Participate in Title IV,
label: BODY

text: HEA Programs.”
label: BODY

text: 44 Refer to Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), Private Student Loans, page 80, August 29, 2012.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: that offer the cosigner release option should keep track of this feature in the loan agreements
label: BODY

text: and fulfill the terms.
label: BODY

text: A key component in underwriting student loan applications is the assessment of affordability
label: BODY

text: of the loan and taking into account the borrowers’ and cosigners’ (if any) ability to meet all
label: BODY

text: debt service requirements for existing and proposed loans. Banks may account for adequate
label: BODY

text: margin in debt service requirements to protect against adverse changes in borrowers’ and
label: BODY

text: cosigners’ (if any) circumstances.
label: BODY

text: When determining ability to repay, the bank’s underwriting criteria rely heavily on the
label: BODY

text: cosigner’s income streams and assets while taking into account all of the cosigner’s
label: BODY

text: obligations. A credible analysis should conclude that the borrower and cosigner can meet all
label: BODY

text: debt service requirements for existing and proposed loans using regularly amortizing
label: BODY

text: payments.
label: BODY

text: In some private student loan programs, borrowers may be able to qualify on their own
label: BODY

text: without the need for cosigners. To qualify, borrowers should have credit scores that meet the
label: BODY

text: program minimums and may need to satisfy any employment, income, or asset requirements.
label: BODY

text: When evaluating borrowers’ and cosigners’ ability to repay, banks should consider all debt
label: BODY

text: obligations, including monthly rent or mortgage, auto loans, other student loans (in
label: BODY

text: repayment and deferment), alimony and child support, minimum credit card payments, and
label: BODY

text: other debt payments.
label: BODY

text: The determination of borrowers’ and cosigners’ ability to repay should be based on reliable
label: BODY

text: information, including documented and verified income. Some of the most common and
label: BODY

text: acceptable documentation includes
label: BODY

text: • recent pay stubs.
label: BODY

text: • W-2 forms.
label: BODY

text: • evidence of payroll direct deposit.
label: BODY

text: • personal or business tax returns.
label: BODY

text: • signed 1099 forms.
label: BODY

text: • verification of employment through employer direct contact.
label: BODY

text: • divorce decree or other legal document to verify child support or alimony payments.
label: BODY

text: • other appropriate documentation, such as a social security award letter and investment
label: BODY

text: statements.
label: BODY

text: Credit Bureau Risk Score
label: BODY

text: As a credit overlay, banks often use credit scores in loan underwriting and rely on credit
label: BODY

text: bureau data to gauge credit history, payment experience, and performance. Credit scores
label: BODY

text: project the probability of future payment performance based on past experience. For some
label: BODY

text: banks, borrowers’ credit scores serve as the key requirement in the decision to approve or
label: BODY

text: decline applications in the underwriting process. Most banks, however, use credit scores for
label: BODY

text: screening and subsequently perform additional review based on other credit criteria.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: As with any other consumer loan product, banks that use credit scores in private student
label: BODY

text: lending should control credit quality by setting appropriate cutoff scores based on acceptable
label: BODY

text: default risk or loss rate. Bank management may change the cutoff credit score, and this
label: BODY

text: change alters the risk profile of the originated loans. The cutoff credit score is one of the
label: BODY

text: control mechanisms for volume (quantity) and profit (quality) in private student loans. As a
label: BODY

text: basic principle, the higher the cutoff credit score, the lower the approval rate and fewer the
label: BODY

text: delinquency problems. Decisions to change the cutoff credit score reflect a change of
label: BODY

text: strategy, a change in quality of applicants, and a change in expected level of profitability.
label: BODY

text: Bank management should ensure that credit scoring models are used appropriately and are
label: BODY

text: functioning effectively. Bank management should
label: BODY

text: • thoroughly understand the credit scoring models.
label: BODY

text: • use credit scoring models for their intended purpose.
label: BODY

text: • validate or revalidate the credit scoring models’ performance regularly.
label: BODY

text: • review tracking reports, including the performance of overrides.
label: BODY

text: • take appropriate action when the credit scoring models’ performance deteriorates,
label: BODY

text: including reviewing bank lending strategies to determine their effect on the credit scoring
label: BODY

text: models; actively managing the credit scoring model cutoff strategies; or developing new
label: BODY

text: credit scoring models.
label: BODY

text: • ensure the credit scoring models comply with fair lending regulations.
label: BODY

text: Credit scoring models used in student lending should be subject to sound model validation
label: BODY

text: processes, including evaluation of conceptual soundness, ongoing monitoring, and outcomes
label: BODY

text: analysis.
label: BODY

text: For a basic explanation of credit score models, refer to OCC Bulletin 1997-24, “Credit
label: BODY

text: Scoring Models: Examiner Guidance,” and OCC Bulletin 2011-12, “Supervisory Guidance
label: BODY

text: on Model Risk Management.”
label: BODY

text: Banks should have credit underwriting criteria that include measurements of borrowers’ and
label: BODY

text: cosigners’ capacity to repay the loans (debt-to-income or payment-to-income), acceptable
label: BODY

text: documentation, cutoff credit score and tolerance for overrides, and school eligibility
label: BODY

text: requirements. Banks that have underwriting standards that are less stringent than industry and
label: BODY

text: market standards should establish portfolio concentration limits on these lesser-qualified
label: BODY

text: borrowers to minimize the banks’ exposure to a manageable level.
label: BODY

text: Loan Feature and Structure
label: BODY

text: Banks offer a range of private student loan features and structures. Interest rates may be fixed
label: BODY

text: or adjustable; repayment terms may be straight amortization or graduated; and repayment
label: BODY

text: periods may be shorter (10 years or less) or longer (over 10 years). Banks generally consider
label: BODY

text: these factors jointly in the qualification process and should develop a range of reasonable
label: BODY

text: tolerances for each factor. Underwriting should be based on prudent and appropriate
label: BODY

text: underwriting standards, taking into account borrowers’ characteristics and private student
label: BODY

text: loan attributes.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Banks that offer graduated repayment terms at origination should follow the prudent
label: BODY

text: standards outlined in OCC Bulletin 2015-7, “Interagency Guidance on Private Student Loans
label: BODY

text: With Graduated Repayment Terms at Origination.” Borrowers and banks generally are best
label: BODY

text: served by amortizing repayment of principal and interest over reasonable periods. When
label: BODY

text: considering graduated repayment terms, banks should promote orderly repayment over the
label: BODY

text: life of the loans. Banks should consider providing longer repayment periods (e.g., 20 years)
label: BODY

text: for larger loans and shorter repayment periods for smaller loans.
label: BODY

text: Maximum Student Debt
label: BODY

text: Banks generally set private student loan amount limits according to the published cost of
label: BODY

text: attendance at the borrowers’ schools, with lifetime caps based on the students’ programs of
label: BODY

text: study. The schools set the overall loan limit for each student based on qualified education
label: BODY

text: expenses up to the cost of attendance, less all other student aid received,45 and any other
label: BODY

text: loans already applied to the cost for the academic year.
label: BODY

text: Banks require school certification or verification of enrollment to ensure that students are
label: BODY

text: borrowing responsibly and that the loan amounts requested do not exceed the borrowers’
label: BODY

text: COA. School financial aid offices certify borrowers’ need for loans and the amount that
label: BODY

text: borrowers are eligible to borrow. School certification provides the following additional
label: BODY

text: information: academic period, enrollment status and grade level, expected graduation date,
label: BODY

text: and disbursement date. Federal law requires that before lenders may disburse private student
label: BODY

text: loans, the lenders must obtain completed and signed self-certification forms46 from
label: BODY

text: borrowers.
label: BODY

text: Disbursement of funds may include certified checks jointly payable to the students and the
label: BODY

text: schools, or electronic funds transfers of loan proceeds to student accounts at the eligible
label: BODY

text: schools. Depending on the loan purpose, there is generally a cumulative limit47 on total loans
label: BODY

text: that banks grant and variation on loan terms (5, 10, 15, 20, or more years).
label: BODY

text: Pricing
label: BODY

text: Pricing is a key component of underwriting. Private student loans can have either a fixed
label: BODY

text: interest rate or a variable interest rate. Fixed-rate loans are determined at the time of
label: BODY

text: application approval and remain the same for the life of the loan. A variable rate is based on
label: BODY

text: an index such as the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR)48 or prime lending rate plus a
label: BODY

text: fixed margin rate determined by borrower and cosigner creditworthiness at the time of
label: BODY

text: application. The variable index rate may change on a monthly or quarterly basis. Banks price
label: BODY

text: 45 Such aid includes grants, scholarships, fellowships, and financial awards.
label: BODY

text: 46 This information is included in the borrower’s financial award letter from the school. The form is also
label: BODY

text: available from the school’s financial aid office.
label: BODY

text: 47 The cumulative limit includes both federal and private student loans.
label: BODY

text: 48 LIBOR is the average interest rate paid on deposits of U.S. dollars in the London market.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: private student loans depending on the risk profiles of borrowers and cosigners. Loans that
label: BODY

text: have cosigners generally are priced significantly lower than those without cosigners.
label: BODY

text: Banks should carefully balance pricing for risk and avoid errors that can threaten the
label: BODY

text: portfolios and their performance. There are consequences if banks price below or above
label: BODY

text: market. Any pricing above market could potentially create adverse selection, meaning only
label: BODY

text: the least creditworthy private student loan borrowers apply. This happens because the lower-
label: BODY

text: risk borrowers take advantage of less costly financing options available to them. The highest-
label: BODY

text: risk borrowers apply for and accept retail credit at almost any rate.
label: BODY

text: Often, banks offer borrower benefits such as an interest rate reduction when repayment
label: BODY

text: begins. The interest rate reduction generally ranges between 25 and 100 basis points and is
label: BODY

text: provided if certain conditions are met, including the borrowers agreeing to automatic debit
label: BODY

text: payments from personal checking or savings accounts, the borrowers making specified
label: BODY

text: consecutive on-time payments, the borrowers graduating or completing programs, or the
label: BODY

text: existence of qualifying bank relationships.
label: BODY

text: Examiners should assess whether the bank has well-defined underwriting criteria that
label: BODY

text: establish prudent risk limits, including minimum credit scores, reasonable debt-to-income
label: BODY

text: ratios, maximum loan amount and duration, and appropriate pricing.
label: BODY

text: Other Requirements
label: BODY

text: Except for continuing education loans, bank loans also require that borrowers be enrolled at
label: BODY

text: least half time. In addition to credit qualification, private student loans are subject to
label: BODY

text: completion of loan applications and consumer credit agreements, verification of application
label: BODY

text: information, self-certification forms, and school certification.
label: BODY

text: Through the school channel, colleges or universities certify the loans. School certification
label: BODY

text: means that the school validates that the student has been accepted and will attend the school
label: BODY

text: through which he or she is applying for the loan. Using the school channel ensures that the
label: BODY

text: borrower obtains only funds necessary for his or her education and that funds are distributed
label: BODY

text: directly to the school, not the borrower. School verification of application includes checking
label: BODY

text: the accuracy of information reported by the student on the FAFSA and may include
label: BODY

text: requesting a copy of the student’s tax returns and, if applicable, the student’s parents’ tax
label: BODY

text: returns.
label: BODY

text: Banks should ensure that funds are being used to pay for borrowers’ tuition and other
label: BODY

text: education expenses. Most banks use the school channel instead of direct-to-consumer
label: BODY

text: channel because the school channel is less susceptible to misuse of funds and fraud. Direct-
label: BODY

text: to-consumer loans generally do not require school certification and can result in borrowers
label: BODY

text: applying for funds in excess of the cost. Banks that use the direct-to-consumer channel
label: BODY

text: release private student loan funds directly to borrowers and lose control over use of the
label: BODY

text: funds.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Banks are expected to follow applicable laws and regulations when underwriting and
label: BODY

text: originating private student loans, including the following:
label: BODY

text: • TILA: All disclosures are made in an accurate and timely manner, as required by TILA.
label: BODY

text: • FCRA: A credit bureau report is requested only if there is a permissible purpose to
label: BODY

text: request it under the FCRA.
label: BODY

text: • ECOA: Loan programs must be administered in a nondiscriminatory manner (including
label: BODY

text: marketing, underwriting, pricing, and servicing), and accurate and consistent adverse
label: BODY

text: action treatment of all declined applications must be documented and followed as
label: BODY

text: required by ECOA.
label: BODY

text: • GLBA: Privacy notices are provided, and information sharing is limited, as required by
label: BODY

text: GLBA.
label: BODY

text: • EFTA: Electronic transfers of loan proceeds to consumers must comply with EFTA
label: BODY

text: requirements.
label: BODY

text: • Unfair or Deceptive Acts or Practices (UDAP) and Unfair, Deceptive, or Abusive
label: BODY

text: Acts or Practices (UDAAP): All elements of marketing, underwriting, and origination
label: BODY

text: must comply with the prohibitions on unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices
label: BODY

text: contained in section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914 and Title X of
label: BODY

text: Dodd–Frank.49
label: BODY

text: Underwriting Exceptions
label: BODY

text: Banks’ private student lending underwriting policies and criteria should reflect the banks’
label: BODY

text: stated risk appetites. Any underwriting exceptions could potentially change the risk profile of
label: BODY

text: approved loans and the portfolios overall. The more discretion injected into the process, the
label: BODY

text: higher the potential for exceptions. Policy exceptions generally are unavoidable because no
label: BODY

text: underwriting policy is comprehensive enough to cover all possible situations. Banks should
label: BODY

text: have the necessary MIS to identify and track exceptions.
label: BODY

text: Banks should establish limitations for each type of exception and monitor adherence to those
label: BODY

text: limits. Reports should track all exceptions to significant underwriting policy, scoring,
label: BODY

text: documentation, and school eligibility requirements. Bank management should ensure that the
label: BODY

text: information is regularly analyzed to determine causes and impacts, and, when necessary,
label: BODY

text: implement corrective action.
label: BODY

text: Examiners should assess whether banks’ private student loan MIS have adequate detail to
label: BODY

text: facilitate analysis of exceptions overall and by type to determine if exceptions significantly
label: BODY

text: affect the portfolios’ risk profiles. To make this determination, examiners should consider the
label: BODY

text: exceptions’ volume and trends and the ongoing performance of loans originated with
label: BODY

text: exceptions. If the performance of loans originated with exceptions is weaker than that of
label: BODY

text: loans conforming to underwriting criteria, bank management should require stricter
label: BODY

text: adherence to underwriting policy. If performance is better, bank management should
label: BODY

text: consider revising bank policy.
label: BODY

text: 49 Refer to OCC Advisory Letter 2002-3, “Guidance on Unfair or Deceptive Acts or Practices,” which sets forth
label: BODY

text: the OCC’s guidance on unfair or deceptive acts or practices.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Exception and performance tracking should be sufficiently granular to enable the board and
label: BODY

text: bank management to drill down into the sources of exceptions. By evaluating exceptions and
label: BODY

text: subsequent performance by product, credit quality, school, channel, etc., bank management
label: BODY

text: can target corrective action to the actual source of any problem.
label: BODY

text: Loan Servicing and Administration
label: BODY

text: Private student loan servicers are responsible for properly administering loans from
label: BODY

text: origination through final payment. Banks or third parties perform student loan servicing.
label: BODY

text: Using reliable third-party servicers can be an effective way to standardize procedures,
label: BODY

text: facilitate growth, and minimize costs. Additionally, third-party servicers are more likely to
label: BODY

text: have the scale, system infrastructure, and, in most cases, personnel experience to carry out
label: BODY

text: any specialized student loan requirements (e.g., use of deferments and grace periods). Banks
label: BODY

text: that use third-party servicers should ensure that loans are administered appropriately and
label: BODY

text: comply with bank policies and procedures and applicable laws and regulations.50 Banks
label: BODY

text: should follow the supervisory guidelines regarding risk management outlined in OCC
label: BODY

text: Bulletin 2013-29, “Third-Party Relationships: Risk Management Guidance.” Banks’ risk
label: BODY

text: management systems should reflect the complexity of banks’ third-party activities and the
label: BODY

text: overall level of risk involved.
label: BODY

text: The following terminology is commonly associated with repayment of student loans:
label: BODY

text: • In-school period: The time during which the borrower is enrolled at least half time at an
label: BODY

text: eligible school. The in-school period ends when the borrower graduates or leaves school,
label: BODY

text: or when the borrower’s enrollment drops below half time.51
label: BODY

text: • In-school deferment: A period during which no payment is required while the borrower
label: BODY

text: is enrolled at a “qualifying” school, per the bank’s definition, as no less than a half-time
label: BODY

text: student.52
label: BODY

text: • Repayment period: The period during which payments of principal and interest are
label: BODY

text: required. The repayment period typically follows any applicable in-school deferment or
label: BODY

text: grace period.
label: BODY

text: • Grace period: A standard six-month period after graduation or withdrawal from school
label: BODY

text: during which no payment is required. This grace period may be automatically granted to
label: BODY

text: a borrower who leaves school or drops below half time before repayment begins.53
label: BODY

text: • Extended grace period: An additional, consecutive, one-time period during which no
label: BODY

text: payment is required for up to six months after the initial grace period. An extended grace
label: BODY

text: period typically is granted to the borrower who may be having difficulty finding
label: BODY

text: 50 These include the FDCPA (15 USC 1692 et seq.) and OCC Bulletin 2014-37, “Consumer Debt Sales: Risk
label: BODY

text: Management Guidance.”
label: BODY

text: 52 Refer to 34 CFR 685.204(b).
label: BODY

text: 53 Refer to 34 CFR 674.2(b).
