text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: employment before the repayment period starts. The extended grace period counts toward
label: BODY

text: the maximum lifetime allowable payment forbearance of no more than 12 months.54
label: BODY

text: Repayment Terms
label: BODY

text: Banks generally offer various repayment options or repayment terms for student loans:
label: BODY

text: • Immediate repayment: This repayment option requires the borrower to begin making
label: BODY

text: principal and interest payments, usually no more than 60 days after the final disbursement
label: BODY

text: date of the loan.
label: BODY

text: • Deferred principal and interest: This option involves full deferment of principal and
label: BODY

text: interest payments during school while capitalizing the accrued interest. Repayment
label: BODY

text: begins six months after the earliest of (1) graduation, (2) the borrower ceasing to be
label: BODY

text: enrolled in school, or (3) the borrower being enrolled less than half time. Banks generally
label: BODY

text: have a limit on how long the deferment lasts, which is usually tied to the expected
label: BODY

text: completion time period of the borrower’s education program.
label: BODY

text: • Fully amortizing repayment: This option involves a periodic loan payment, part of
label: BODY

text: which is principal and part of which is interest. If the borrower makes payments
label: BODY

text: according to the loan’s amortization schedule, the loan will be paid off by the end of its
label: BODY

text: term. The borrower and the bank generally are best served by amortizing repayments of
label: BODY

text: principal and interest over a reasonable time period.
label: BODY

text: • Graduated repayment: This repayment structure allows for lower monthly payments
label: BODY

text: that gradually increase. Banks that offer this option at origination should follow safe and
label: BODY

text: sound lending practices and regulatory principles outlined in OCC Bulletin 2015-7,
label: BODY

text: “Interagency Guidance on Private Student Loans With Graduated Repayment Terms at
label: BODY

text: Origination.” Banks may offer borrowers graduated repayment terms in addition to fixed
label: BODY

text: amortizing terms and provide flexibility to repay the debt sooner if borrowers’ incomes
label: BODY

text: increase more quickly than projected. When underwriting private student loans with
label: BODY

text: graduated repayment, banks should consider aligning payment terms with the borrower’s
label: BODY

text: income. Banks should establish the time period during which graduated repayment terms
label: BODY

text: will be offered, usually at the beginning of the repayment period.
label: BODY

text: • Interest only: Some banks may require some form of in-school repayment that includes
label: BODY

text: full or nominal interest payment. Interest-only payments generally begin no more than
label: BODY

text: 60 days after the final disbursement date.
label: BODY

text: Loan servicing includes all activities during the in-school, grace, and repayment periods.
label: BODY

text: Loan servicing includes various activities, such as
label: BODY

text: • verifying the borrower’s in-school status.
label: BODY

text: • transitioning to loan repayment.
label: BODY

text: • establishing repayment terms.
label: BODY

text: • applying payments.
label: BODY

text: 54 Refer to Chief National Bank Examiner Policy Guidance (CNBE) 2010-2 (REV), “Policy Interpretation:
label: BODY

text: OCC Bulletin 2000-20—Application to Private Student Lending.” This policy guidance previously was
label: BODY

text: available only internally to OCC employees and is made public with this booklet.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: • granting deferment and forbearance.
label: BODY

text: • reporting loan information to credit bureaus.
label: BODY

text: • responding to inquiries.
label: BODY

text: The loan servicer receives and processes updated enrollment information through various
label: BODY

text: processes, including certification from applications, deferment forms, letters from a school
label: BODY

text: official, the National Student Loan Data System—Student Status Confirmation Report
label: BODY

text: (NSLDS-SSCR)55 process, and direct communication from the school. When the loan
label: BODY

text: servicer is notified that the borrower is no longer attending school or is not carrying the
label: BODY

text: required credits, the borrower generally enters a grace period. The grace period is intended to
label: BODY

text: provide the borrower with time to find employment and prepare to repay the loan. The
label: BODY

text: borrower is generally allowed a six-month grace period before loan repayment begins.
label: BODY

text: During the grace period, the loan servicer is generally expected to establish a relationship
label: BODY

text: with the borrower to help the borrower understand his or her repayment status and
label: BODY

text: obligations, promote any self-service payment option offered by the bank (e.g., online), and
label: BODY

text: obtain updated borrower contact information. The loan servicer should help educate and
label: BODY

text: inform the borrower regarding the tools and options available to assist him or her in
label: BODY

text: managing the student loan and options to receive bill correspondence electronically.
label: BODY

text: Management should ensure that loan servicers adhere to applicable federal laws and
label: BODY

text: regulations, including the following:
label: BODY

text: • ECOA (Regulation B)
label: BODY

text: • EFTA (Regulation E)
label: BODY

text: • FCRA (Regulation V)
label: BODY

text: • FDCPA
label: BODY

text: • “Privacy of Consumer Financial Information” (Regulation P)
label: BODY

text: • USA PATRIOT Act
label: BODY

text: • TILA (Regulation Z)
label: BODY

text: • SCRA
label: BODY

text: • MLA
label: BODY

text: Because private student loans are unsecured debt and not federally guaranteed, loan servicers
label: BODY

text: need to be highly proficient in ensuring that loans are properly originated and appropriately
label: BODY

text: serviced. If banks use third-party servicers, these servicers generally indemnify banks and
label: BODY

text: hold them harmless from liability for any deficiency in originating or servicing student loans.
label: BODY

text: Indemnification is considered best practice when using third-party servicers. The strength of
label: BODY

text: the indemnification is closely tied to the third party’s financial condition, and importantly,
label: BODY

text: indemnification provisions are not a substitute for proper risk-management practices.
label: BODY

text: 55 The NSLDS is a national database of information on Title IV aid, including FFELP loans. The NSLDS was
label: BODY

text: developed to provide loan-level information on Title IV loans and to provide an integrated view of other Title
label: BODY

text: IV programs. NSLDS overall goals are to improve the quality and accessibility of student aid data, reduce the
label: BODY

text: burden of administering Title IV aid, and minimize abuse within the aid programs through accurate tracking of
label: BODY

text: funds awarded to assist the postsecondary students for whom the programs were designed.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Examiners should expect banks to have a sound third-party program that includes periodic
label: BODY

text: due diligence, review, and monitoring. Banks should conduct periodic on-site third-party
label: BODY

text: servicer audits to assess whether the third parties are adhering to the banks’ private student
label: BODY

text: loan policies and procedures. Banks should have third-party metrics and appropriate MIS
label: BODY

text: reports that include loan performance by third-party servicers. One of the key components of
label: BODY

text: a third-party servicer program is a Statement on Standards for Attestation Engagements
label: BODY

text: Number 16 review (SSAE 16). This annual review helps monitor third-party servicers’
label: BODY

text: operational soundness and ability to comply with bank policies and procedures and
label: BODY

text: applicable laws and regulations. Bank management should have appropriate processes and
label: BODY

text: procedures when third-party servicers are given unacceptable or equivalent ratings during
label: BODY

text: annual reviews.
label: BODY

text: Bank management should be mindful of student loan servicing deficiencies highlighted by
label: BODY

text: the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)56 in its annual ombudsman reports.57
label: BODY

text: Collections
label: BODY

text: In most banks, whether done in-house or through third parties, loan servicing is responsible
label: BODY

text: for loan collections of private student loans. Loan servicers have specialized collections staff
label: BODY

text: whose responsibilities may involve the collections of both private and federal guaranteed
label: BODY

text: student loans. Whether private or federal, student loans are generally difficult to discharge in
label: BODY

text: bankruptcy. There are time limits or statutes of limitations, however, on how long private
label: BODY

text: student lenders can try to collect on the underlying debt. These time limits or statutes of
label: BODY

text: limitation vary by state but are usually about three to six years.58 If banks sue and obtain
label: BODY

text: court judgments, the banks may have from five to as many as 20 years to enforce court
label: BODY

text: judgments.
label: BODY

text: Because student loans are unsecured consumer debt, loan servicers should take appropriate
label: BODY

text: steps to avoid loan defaults by borrowers. Delinquent loans should be actively managed and
label: BODY

text: collections efforts effectively performed. Once loans enter the repayment phase, the
label: BODY

text: servicers’ main objectives are to collect payments, pursue delinquent accounts, and minimize
label: BODY

text: loan defaults while providing effective customer service.
label: BODY

text: An effective student loan collection process is a key component of controlling and
label: BODY

text: minimizing credit losses. Whether performed by a third party or in-house, the process should
label: BODY

text: be guided by well-established policies and procedures and should be managed effectively at
label: BODY

text: each stage for optimal and legal collection of principal and interest to occur. Private student
label: BODY

text: loan servicers must adhere to the FDCPA, which prohibits abusive debt collection practices.
label: BODY

text: 56 Dodd–Frank establishes an ombudsman for student loans within the CFPB who is responsible for making
label: BODY

text: “appropriate recommendations” to the CFPB Director, the Secretary of the Treasury, the Secretary of
label: BODY

text: Education, and Congress.
label: BODY

text: 57 Refer to Annual Report of the CFPB Student Loan Ombudsman, 2012, 2013, and 2014.
label: BODY

text: 58 Refer to “State-by-State List of Statute of Limitations on Debt.”
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: The problems associated with an inadequately managed collection function include
label: BODY

text: • reduced earnings caused by increased loan losses and reduced recoveries.
label: BODY

text: • inaccurate or untimely communications to senior management and the directorate.
label: BODY

text: • inaccurate reporting of past-due and charged-off loans, and imprudent management
label: BODY

text: decisions.
label: BODY

text: • insufficient allowance for loan losses caused by weak MIS, inaccurate past due figures,
label: BODY

text: and the improper use of deferment, forbearance, and other collection-related practices.
label: BODY

text: • inadequate audit trail of collection and recovery activities.
label: BODY

text: • poorly trained employees, resulting in loss of productivity, collections, and recoveries.
label: BODY

text: • violations of laws and regulations.
label: BODY

text: Technology
label: BODY

text: The loan collection function generally relies on automation and technology to be
label: BODY

text: competitive, remain compliant, operate efficiently, and increase profitability. Banks and third
label: BODY

text: parties generally use technology and historical information to formulate a plan or strategy for
label: BODY

text: optimizing their collection efforts. Communication technology has grown in sophistication
label: BODY

text: over time. This technology is used to leverage an integrated and multi-channel approach to
label: BODY

text: borrower communication with voice alerts, outbound interactive voice response, predictive
label: BODY

text: dialing, preview calling, e-mails, and custom websites. Even skip tracing techniques have
label: BODY

text: evolved and use social media to locate borrowers. Whatever form of communication banks or
label: BODY

text: third parties use to contact borrowers, privacy is a significant consideration. Banks must
label: BODY

text: adhere to the FDCPA and other applicable laws and regulations, including state dialer and
label: BODY

text: messaging restrictions, operator and consent rules, and rules addressing identification data
label: BODY

text: blocks, drop rates, call times, and other subjects.
label: BODY

text: In contrast with communication technology used in the loan collection function, the
label: BODY

text: infrastructure used to administer and service private student loans has limited functionality.
label: BODY

text: These are generally legacy systems designed primarily to support repayment options offered
label: BODY

text: in the federal guaranteed loan programs.59 These platforms were not designed to
label: BODY

text: accommodate TDR60 analysis and financial reporting requirements. Consequently, some
label: BODY

text: workout options for private student loans (e.g., restructuring or modifications) would likely
label: BODY

text: require platform technology enhancements.
label: BODY

text: Examiners should have a general understanding of the technologies employed by in-house
label: BODY

text: collection departments or third parties to evaluate their effectiveness. Bank management
label: BODY

text: should appropriately oversee and govern third-party relationships, and there should be no
label: BODY

text: 59 Examples include the Graduated Repayment Plan, Income-Contingent Repayment Term, Extended
label: BODY

text: Repayment, and Income-Based Repayment. Refer to appendix E of this booklet for more information.
label: BODY

text: 60 Accounting Standards Codification Subtopic 310-40 states that a TDR is “a restructuring in which a bank, for
label: BODY

text: economic or other reasons related to a borrower’s financial difficulties, grants a concession to the borrower that
label: BODY

text: it would not otherwise consider.” Accounting Standards Codification 310-40-15-9 states that a TDR includes “a
label: BODY

text: modification of the loan terms, such as a reduction of the stated interest rate, principal, or accrued interest or an
label: BODY

text: extension of the maturity date at a stated interest rate lower than the current market rate for new debt with
label: BODY

text: similar risk.”
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Management and Control Systems
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: gaps in banks’ information technology risk management programs. If loan servicers are using
label: BODY

text: work-arounds to adhere to requirements of TDR enhanced accounting and reporting,
label: BODY

text: examiners should ensure that the banks have the appropriate internal controls.
label: BODY

text: Collection Strategies
label: BODY

text: Collection strategies determine which accounts are put in collection queues, the timing of
label: BODY

text: collection activities, and the type of contact (e.g., phone calls, collection letters, and legal
label: BODY

text: letters). Seasonality is a factor in private student loan collections. Borrowers who graduate in
label: BODY

text: December begin repayment after the six-month grace period. That is why many accounts
label: BODY

text: enter first payment default between May and June. By the same token, borrowers who
label: BODY

text: graduate in May enter the collection queue in the fourth quarter of the year. Bank
label: BODY

text: management should adjust its collection strategies and staffing to accommodate this
label: BODY

text: seasonality.
label: BODY

text: Most banks with effective loan collection units engage in delinquency prevention. Some of
label: BODY

text: the most common strategies they employ are the following:
label: BODY

text: • Early withdrawal strategy: Banks send high-level e-mails and perform outbound calls
label: BODY

text: to borrowers who withdrew from school and provide counseling on repayment options
label: BODY

text: during the grace period. The goal of the strategy is to reduce loan defaults for this
label: BODY

text: population.
label: BODY

text: • Pre-repayment strategy: Banks generally make outbound calls to borrowers who
label: BODY

text: recently graduated and borrowers coming out of forbearance. These calls educate
label: BODY

text: customers on the amount and due date of their payments, methods of payment, and bank
label: BODY

text: contact information (e.g., website, e-mail, phone number, and address). This strategy is
label: BODY

text: also helpful in determining if skip tracing is necessary.
label: BODY

text: Another consideration in private student loan collection is borrower mobility. New graduates
label: BODY

text: may move immediately after graduation or separation from school. Banks recognize that
label: BODY

text: some student loan defaults result from failure to locate borrowers or otherwise having no
label: BODY

text: contact with borrowers. Default and debt management programs can work only when banks
label: BODY

text: can locate borrowers. Pre-repayment strategies that include soliciting updated borrower and
label: BODY

text: cosigner information, including cellphone numbers, have proved to be effective. These
label: BODY

text: efforts help borrowers transition from deferment and the grace period into making payments.
label: BODY

text: In many banks, collection strategies rely on behavior scoring models to segment accounts by
label: BODY

text: risk. Transaction analytics also help in developing effective behavior score models that adapt
label: BODY

text: or adjust to portfolio changes. High-risk accounts should have higher collection phone call
label: BODY

text: attempts and customer contacts to increase likelihood of collection. Banks use behavior score
label: BODY

text: models to predict likelihood of collection and to more precisely alter banks’ actions and
label: BODY

text: timing for collection activity. Banks use analytics and segmentation to determine not only the
label: BODY

text: appropriate collection action but also whether to send accounts to third-party collection
label: BODY

text: agencies and at what point to do so. Examiners should review and discuss with bank
label: BODY

text: management the collection strategies and reports generated. Banks should maintain close
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: control over their collection strategies and understand the impact of strategy changes to
label: BODY

text: dollars collected.
label: BODY

text: Supervision of collection staff is important. Bank management should ensure that collection
label: BODY

text: supervisors have appropriate collections experience and good management skills. Bank
label: BODY

text: management should align incentives with collection goals and collector performance
label: BODY

text: measures, and should require that collection supervisors regularly review the collectors’
label: BODY

text: performance. Collection activities should be subject to regular quality assurance and internal
label: BODY

text: audit review.
label: BODY

text: Internal Audit
label: BODY

text: Because of the variety of risks inherent in private student lending activities, internal audit
label: BODY

text: coverage should include evaluating all the risks and controls in the bank’s private student
label: BODY

text: lending operations. The scope and frequency of these audits should be based on the risk of
label: BODY

text: associated controls and complexity of banks’ private student lending activities. Internal audit
label: BODY

text: staff should be able to identify control breakdowns and ensure appropriate remediation.
label: BODY

text: Internal audit should assess strategic business risks and the overall risk management
label: BODY

text: framework, including complying with bank policies, approved practices and limits, and
label: BODY

text: applicable laws and regulations. Internal audit staff should be independent and
label: BODY

text: knowledgeable about private student lending activities.
label: BODY

text: Staff should report audit findings, including identified control weaknesses, to the board or a
label: BODY

text: designated committee. The board and bank management should ensure that the internal audit
label: BODY

text: staff has the necessary qualifications and expertise to review private student lending
label: BODY

text: activities.
label: BODY

text: Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: BODY

text: Classification and Charge-Off Policies
label: BODY

text: Private student loan account classification and charge-off practices are addressed in OCC
label: BODY

text: Bulletin 2000-20, “Uniform Retail Credit Classification and Account Management Policy:
label: BODY

text: Policy Implementation.” In general, under this policy, private student loans that reach
label: BODY

text: 90 days past due are classified “substandard,” and loans that become 120 days past due are
label: BODY

text: classified as a loss and charged off. The guidance includes special rules for bankrupt,
label: BODY

text: fraudulent, and deceased borrower accounts, and examiners should review this bulletin
label: BODY

text: closely before considering banks’ collection activities.
label: BODY

text: For private student loans, just because loans are classified as a loss or charged off does not
label: BODY

text: mean that the lender should stop using workout or modification programs or that loss
label: BODY

text: mitigation or collection efforts should cease, unless prohibited by law. It simply means that
label: BODY

text: for safety and soundness reasons and financial and investor transparency, banks should
label: BODY

text: follow appropriate accounting practices.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: MIS for Collections
label: BODY

text: The volume and trends in delinquencies and losses are central to evaluating collections and
label: BODY

text: overall portfolio performance. Robust, timely MIS reporting identifies loans or portfolio
label: BODY

text: segments that are not performing as expected and helps bank management understand
label: BODY

text: portfolio quality. The bank’s set of MIS reports on private student loans should give bank
label: BODY

text: management a view of loans that are in repayment, as well as the range of loss mitigation and
label: BODY

text: collection activities in which the bank engages. The reports should provide bank
label: BODY

text: management with a comprehensive and accurate view of the portfolio’s risk including
label: BODY

text: tracking effectiveness of the bank’s forbearance, workout, and modification programs.
label: BODY

text: Through bank MIS reports, bank management should be able to isolate key products, product
label: BODY

text: combinations, and borrower characteristics to help understand which factors drive
label: BODY

text: performance. Besides helping management track portfolio performance against expectations,
label: BODY

text: bank MIS reports should assist in understanding policy limitations and enable management to
label: BODY

text: benchmark against industry metrics.
label: BODY

text: MIS reports should not only support the collection process but also help ensure timely
label: BODY

text: recognition of losses.
label: BODY

text: Because of the nature of student loans, there could be a significant time lag between the
label: BODY

text: disbursement of loan funds and the start of repayment. Therefore, any private student loan
label: BODY

text: MIS should provide portfolio metrics that clearly distinguish the account status (in repayment
label: BODY

text: versus deferment).
label: BODY

text: Equally or even more important, MIS reports should help bank management understand the
label: BODY

text: factors influencing portfolio performance (e.g., underwriting, marketing, and collection
label: BODY

text: staffing). Understanding these factors promotes a more realistic assessment of portfolio
label: BODY

text: performance as well as an accurate evaluation of the workload and effectiveness of the
label: BODY

text: bank’s collection function. MIS helps ensure that remedial actions implemented are properly
label: BODY

text: constructed to address the problem rather than a symptom. For example, private student loan
label: BODY

text: MIS should have appropriate segmentation and granularity necessary to monitor performance
label: BODY

text: for each school or education program based on delinquencies and losses. This granularity of
label: BODY

text: MIS reports helps bank management evaluate school relationships and terminate poorly
label: BODY

text: performing relationships and programs when necessary.
label: BODY

text: The roll rate report,61 for example, allows bank management to review the number and dollar
label: BODY

text: volume of accounts that move from current to 30-days delinquent, 30- to 60-days, etc. This
label: BODY

text: information helps management to predict the charge-off rate as far as six months into the
label: BODY

text: future. In addition, this report can aid management decisions regarding collection staffing
label: BODY

text: levels.
label: BODY

text: 61 Roll rates measure the movement of accounts and balances from one payment status to another (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: percentage of accounts or dollars that were current last month rolling to 30 days past due this month).
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Examiners should evaluate the bank’s MIS for timely, accurate, relevant, and effective
label: BODY

text: information and should strongly criticize the absence of appropriate tracking and monitoring
label: BODY

text: reports.
label: BODY

text: Workout Program and Debt Management
label: BODY

text: The Education Department allows several repayment and debt management62 alternatives for
label: BODY

text: financially distressed borrowers with federal student loans. These repayment alternatives
label: BODY

text: include extended repayment plans such as graduated repayment, income-contingent
label: BODY

text: repayment term, extended repayment, and income-based repayment. Debt forgiveness is
label: BODY

text: another alternative. Some of these alternatives may not be appropriate for private student
label: BODY

text: loans and may not be consistent with safe and sound banking principles. The Education
label: BODY

text: Department defines federal student loan default as 270 days past due, compared with
label: BODY

text: 120 days past due for banks’ private student loans. The Education Department also allows
label: BODY

text: loan deferment due to unemployment for a maximum of three years. These Education
label: BODY

text: Department programs and practices have brought pressure to banks to align their repayment
label: BODY

text: and workout programs for private student loans to those of federal student loans. Banks have
label: BODY

text: some latitude to offer similar federal workout programs to private student loans. Banks,
label: BODY

text: however, should do so while adhering to safety and soundness requirements and following
label: BODY

text: existing banking guidance and GAAP.
label: BODY

text: Two OCC issuances provide guidance related to student loan deferment, forbearance, and
label: BODY

text: modifications. First, OCC Bulletin 2000-20, “Uniform Retail Credit Classification and
label: BODY

text: Account Management Policy: Policy Implementation,” provides general guidance on
label: BODY

text: classifying retail credits for regulatory purposes and establishing policies for working with
label: BODY

text: borrowers experiencing temporary financial difficulties. Second, the examiner guidance,
label: BODY

text: CNBE Policy Guidance 2010-2 (REV), “Policy Interpretation: OCC Bulletin 2000-20—
label: BODY

text: Application to Private Student Lending,” affirms the applicability and fundamental principles
label: BODY

text: of the Retail Classification Policy to private student lending while recognizing the unique
label: BODY

text: aspects of higher education financing.63
label: BODY

text: OCC Bulletin 2000-20 and CNBE Policy Guidance 2010-2 (REV) address supervisory
label: BODY

text: expectations for risk management of loan workout programs and arrangements, classification
label: BODY

text: of loans, and regulatory reporting and accounting considerations. Examiners and bankers
label: BODY

text: should remember that workout programs can be used to help borrowers overcome temporary
label: BODY

text: financial difficulties, if those actions
label: BODY

text: • do not cloud the true performance and delinquency status of the portfolio.
label: BODY

text: • are reported accurately for call report and financial reporting purposes.
label: BODY

text: • are based on the borrower’s renewed willingness and ability to repay the loan.
label: BODY

text: • are structured and controlled in accordance with sound internal policies.
label: BODY

text: 62 Workout programs are commonly referred to as “debt management” in the student lending industry.
label: BODY

text: 63 This policy guidance previously was available only internally to OCC employees and is being made public
label: BODY

text: with this booklet.

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Bank management should note that regulatory agencies encourage financial institutions to
label: BODY

text: work constructively with private student loan borrowers experiencing financial difficulties
label: BODY

text: and should consider workout arrangements that increase the potential for such borrowers to
label: BODY

text: repay private student loans whenever workout arrangements are economically feasible and
label: BODY

text: appropriate.64 Banks should adopt their own standards for workouts and modifications and
label: BODY

text: monitor the effectiveness of those standards. Banks should provide clear and practical
label: BODY

text: information to student loan borrowers that explains the options available, general eligibility
label: BODY

text: criteria, the process for requesting workouts, and information on how to contact lenders or
label: BODY

text: loan servicers.
label: BODY

text: There are several repayment assistance remedies unique to private student loans, some of
label: BODY

text: which are described in this section.
label: BODY

text: Deferment
label: BODY

text: In-school deferment is a temporary postponement of payments while borrowers are attending
label: BODY

text: school (enrolled at least half time). Repayment of private student loans generally begins
label: BODY

text: 60 days after disbursement. Most borrowers opt for in-school deferment of principal and
label: BODY

text: interest. During this period, the interest is capitalized and added to the principal balance of
label: BODY

text: the loan. Repayment then begins six months after graduation, when borrowers are no longer
label: BODY

text: enrolled in school, or when borrowers are enrolled less than half time. Banks tie the length of
label: BODY

text: deferment to the expected completion time of borrowers’ education programs. Deferment
label: BODY

text: should not affect other terms of the loan, including maturity.
label: BODY

text: Six-month grace is a standard period after graduation or withdrawal from school during
label: BODY

text: which no payment is required, as interest continues to be capitalized. This grace period is
label: BODY

text: automatically granted to borrowers who leave school or drop below half time before
label: BODY

text: repayment begins. This grace period is ordinarily granted without conditions or
label: BODY

text: documentation of any hardship. During the grace period, banks should contact borrowers to
label: BODY

text: counsel them on repayment terms, the repayment process, and repayment responsibilities to
label: BODY

text: ensure orderly transition to repayment.
label: BODY

text: Forbearance and Extension
label: BODY

text: Forbearance permits borrowers to temporarily postpone making payments or reduce the
label: BODY

text: amount of payments for a limited and specific period if borrowers are unable to make the
label: BODY

text: scheduled loan payments for reasons including temporary financial hardship. Borrowers are
label: BODY

text: liable for the interest that accrues on loans during the forbearance period. Forbearance is
label: BODY

text: granted at banks’ discretion. Private student loans with repayment terms of 10 years or
label: BODY

text: greater may have no more than 12 months of payment forbearance over the loans’ terms.
label: BODY

text: Banks should establish a lesser limit for loans with terms of less than 10 years.
label: BODY

text: Banks should consider granting forbearances for private student loans in one- or two-month
label: BODY

text: increments, with three- to six-month forbearance terms granted only in exceptional
label: BODY

text: 64 Refer to OCC, “Agencies Encourage Lenders to Work With Student Loan Borrowers,” news release 2013-
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: circumstances. There should be a 12-month period of positive payment performance before
label: BODY

text: borrowers are eligible for subsequent forbearance. The two types of forbearance that banks
label: BODY

text: should consider as possible remedies for short-term borrower hardship are extended grace
label: BODY

text: and extensions. Both forbearance actions are consistent with existing OCC guidance.
label: BODY

text: • Extended grace is the period immediately after the grace period during which borrowers
label: BODY

text: experiencing financial hardship are allowed an additional grace period of up to six
label: BODY

text: months. Extended grace may be granted with appropriate documentation and gives
label: BODY

text: borrowers a total of up to 12 months after graduation or withdrawal from school to obtain
label: BODY

text: employment (grace period plus extended grace period) and begin repayment.65
label: BODY

text: Examiners should assess whether banks contact borrowers to document and support the
label: BODY

text: hardship requiring this forbearance option, establish borrowers’ commitment to repay the
label: BODY

text: debt, and evaluate the reasonableness of borrowers’ prospective repayment capacity after
label: BODY

text: the extended grace period.
label: BODY

text: • Extension is a form of forbearance used to roll back the maturity of loans by a specified
label: BODY

text: number of months (e.g., one or two months). Accounts are shown to be current upon
label: BODY

text: granting extensions.
label: BODY

text: The extended grace period and all extensions should count toward the maximum lifetime
label: BODY

text: allowable payment forbearance of no more than 12 months. The limits on extensions are
label: BODY

text: calculated on a per-loan basis. Management should consider incremental approval of the
label: BODY

text: extended grace period and document ongoing conversations with borrowers to determine if
label: BODY

text: borrowers have established means to repay the debt. Banks should notify cosigners of the
label: BODY

text: approval of any extended grace period or other payment forbearance.
label: BODY

text: Examiners should assess whether bank practices that defer the start of the repayment period
label: BODY

text: are well controlled, supported, and documented to prevent the inappropriate deferral of loss
label: BODY

text: recognition in problem situations. Short-term forbearance for temporary hardship is typically
label: BODY

text: not considered a TDR. A determination, however, should be made if a TDR exists if the
label: BODY

text: modification is significant to the term, contractual balance, or other characteristics of the
label: BODY

text: loan, and consistent with GAAP.
label: BODY

text: Military Deferment and Forbearance
label: BODY

text: In the case of an in-school military deferment, members of the military attending school
label: BODY

text: (enrolled at least half time) and called into active duty66 or qualifying National Guard duty67
label: BODY

text: should be allowed deferment in increments of 12 months (maximum of 36 months).
label: BODY

text: 65 CNBE Policy Guidance 2010-2 (REV), “Policy Interpretation: OCC Bulletin 2000-20—Application to
label: BODY

text: Private Student Lending.”
label: BODY

text: 66 The term “active duty” is defined in 10 USC 101(d)(1). Also refer to 10 USC 688 12301(a), 10 USC 688
label: BODY

text: 67 Qualifying National Guard duty refers to activation, reassignment, and full-time duty in connection with war,
label: BODY

text: contingency operation, or national emergency. Refer to 10 USC 12301. The term “National Guard duty” is
label: BODY

text: defined in 10 USC 101(d)(1), 10 USC 101(d)(3), and 10 USC 101(d)(5).
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Examiners should assess whether banks review borrowers’ military status after each 12-
label: BODY

text: month deferment term.
label: BODY

text: For borrowers who are out of school, in repayment status, and called into active duty or
label: BODY

text: qualifying National Guard duty, banks may grant a similar 12-month deferment (maximum
label: BODY

text: of 36 months) on an exception basis recognizing the borrowers’ reduced capacity to repay.
label: BODY

text: For military deferment and forbearance, examiners should verify whether bank management
label: BODY

text: • checks active duty papers to confirm mobilization or call to active duty.68
label: BODY

text: • provides the borrower education and counseling that include disclosure of capitalization
label: BODY

text: of interest and non-waiver of principal during forbearance to both borrowers and
label: BODY

text: cosigners.
label: BODY

text: • monitors and tracks military forbearance granted with appropriate internal controls, MIS,
label: BODY

text: and quality assurance.
label: BODY

text: Additionally, banks must follow laws and regulations, including the SCRA, that apply to
label: BODY

text: service members. This law provides various civil protections and rights to service members.
label: BODY

text: Among the protections is a 6 percent interest rate cap on pre-service debts69 and restrictions
label: BODY

text: on default judgments against members in active duty military service. The U.S. Department
label: BODY

text: of Justice may pursue enforcement actions for SCRA claims against lenders through the
label: BODY

text: agency’s Civil Rights Division. Similarly, the OCC may consider what supervisory response,
label: BODY

text: including taking an enforcement action, is appropriate if one of its supervised banks violates
label: BODY

text: the SCRA.
label: BODY

text: Long-Term Hardship
label: BODY

text: Banks should work with borrowers experiencing long-term financial hardship in a
label: BODY

text: constructive way. For long-term hardships, banks may temporarily or permanently offer
label: BODY

text: workout programs that include modification or restructure. Private student loans, however,
label: BODY

text: should not be treated differently from other retail loans. The terms of any workout programs
label: BODY

text: should be consistent with the nature of borrowers’ hardship, have sustainable payment
label: BODY

text: requirements, and promote orderly, systematic repayment of amounts owed. Banks should
label: BODY

text: structure workout terms based on borrowers’ and cosigners’ (if any) renewed willingness and
label: BODY

text: ability to repay the loans. Banks should be cautioned against workouts that suspend
label: BODY

text: repayment for protracted periods without sufficient documentation of borrowers’ hardship or
label: BODY

text: willingness and reasonably expected ability to repay. Workouts should be controlled in
label: BODY

text: accordance with sound bank workout policies.
label: BODY

text: 68 Banks may review call to active duty beginning and end date or access the U.S. Department of Defense
label: BODY

text: database.
label: BODY

text: 69 Pursuant to 50 USC 3937 (SCRA), “Maximum Rate of Interest on Debts Incurred Before Military Service,”
label: BODY

text: the term “interest” includes service charges, renewal charges, fees, or any other charges (except bona fide
label: BODY

text: insurance) with respect to an obligation or liability.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: For long-term hardships, banks may temporarily or permanently reduce the interest rate to
label: BODY

text: lower borrowers’ payments. Any temporary reduction in borrowers’ interest rates should
label: BODY

text: provide reasonable transitions back to the contract rate to avoid payment shock. Conversely,
label: BODY

text: extensions of loan terms or allowing non-amortizing payments or balloon payments at
label: BODY

text: maturity are generally not appropriate actions for long-term hardships because there has not
label: BODY

text: been any demonstrated ability by borrowers to repay.
label: BODY

text: In determining whether to criticize banks with troubled private student loans, examiners
label: BODY

text: should consider whether banks have offered appropriate modifications to borrowers,
label: BODY

text: including restructured loans that result in adverse credit classifications or TDR under GAAP.
label: BODY

text: By the same token, potential or actual treatment as a TDR should not prevent banks from
label: BODY

text: proactively working with borrowers to restructure loans with reasonable modified terms.
label: BODY

text: Consideration and evaluation of cosigners and guarantors should guide the decision and
label: BODY

text: selection of the best borrower option. Any private student loan restructure should be
label: BODY

text: supported by a current, well-documented credit evaluation of borrowers’ and cosigners’ (if
label: BODY

text: any) financial condition and prospects for repayment under the revised terms.
label: BODY

text: Banks should evaluate whether restructured private student loans should be reported as a
label: BODY

text: TDR. Not all modifications of loan terms, however, automatically result in a TDR. For
label: BODY

text: example, if the modified terms are consistent with market conditions and representative of
label: BODY

text: terms that borrowers could obtain in the open market given similar credit characteristics, the
label: BODY

text: restructured loan is not considered a TDR.70
label: BODY

text: For reporting purposes, a restructured loan is considered a TDR when banks, for economic or
label: BODY

text: legal reasons related to borrowers’ financial difficulties, grant concessions to borrowers in
label: BODY

text: modifying or renewing loans that the banks would not otherwise consider. Modifications of
label: BODY

text: loan terms, such as extensions of the maturity date or reductions of the stated interest rate
label: BODY

text: lower than the current market rate for new debt with similar risk, are considered concessions
label: BODY

text: and qualify as a restructuring under GAAP. Private student loans that have undergone TDRs
label: BODY

text: in compliance with their modified terms should be reported as restructured loans in schedule
label: BODY

text: RC-C, part I, memorandum item 1, of the call report.
label: BODY

text: Additionally, banks should evaluate whether accrual of interest remains appropriate for
label: BODY

text: private student loan TDRs. Non-accrual reporting status for individual private student loans
label: BODY

text: is not specifically required, but banks should take steps to ensure that the net income is not
label: BODY

text: materially overstated.
label: BODY

text: Guidance on reporting TDRs, including characteristics of modifications, is included in the
label: BODY

text: Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council (FFIEC) call report instructions and OCC
label: BODY

text: Bulletin 2012-10, “Troubled Debt Restructurings: Supervisory Guidance on Accounting and
label: BODY

text: Reporting Requirements.”
label: BODY

text: 70 Bank Accounting Advisory Series, Topic 2A, question 1, September 2015.
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Examination Considerations
label: BODY

text: Standards, policies, and procedures: When examining banks’ student lending workout
label: BODY

text: programs, examiners should understand the different workout arrangements and determine if
label: BODY

text: banks have prudent workout standards and eligibility criteria that control the use of and limit
label: BODY

text: the number and frequency of forbearances, extensions, deferments, and modifications. The
label: BODY

text: standards should prohibit any additional advances to finance unpaid interest and fees.
label: BODY

text: Examiners should assess whether banks have
label: BODY

text: • standards, policies, and procedures that determine borrowers’ financial condition and
label: BODY

text: overall capacity to repay through evaluation of income, employment, and other debts.
label: BODY

text: • approval and reporting requirements.
label: BODY

text: • program eligibility criteria tailored toward borrowers’ financial difficulty, including
label: BODY

text: temporary, short-term, or long-term difficulty.
label: BODY

text: Examiners should assess bank practices by (1) reviewing the analysis that supports the
label: BODY

text: banks’ decision to offer workout arrangements, and (2) evaluating whether banks adhere to
label: BODY

text: their standards, policies, and procedures. Examiners should evaluate whether banks consider
label: BODY

text: the nature of borrower hardship and whether there is a reasonable basis to support repayment
label: BODY

text: in the future. Examiners should sample several accounts to ensure that bank workout
label: BODY

text: practices adhere to bank policy and that bank practices and policy are consistent with OCC
label: BODY

text: guidance.
label: BODY

text: Documentation and MIS: Banks’ decisions to grant deferment, forbearance, extension,
label: BODY

text: modification, or any other workout arrangement should be supported in the banks’ MIS.
label: BODY

text: Bank documentation should show that there was communication between the borrowers and
label: BODY

text: the banks and that borrowers have the ability to repay the loans. Examiners should review
label: BODY

text: bank MIS and evaluate if banks have adequate MIS that identify and document any private
label: BODY

text: student loans placed in workout programs, including the number of times such action has
label: BODY

text: been taken.
label: BODY

text: Management oversight: There are risks in lax management supervision of workout
label: BODY

text: programs, including accumulation of problem accounts and understatement of portfolio
label: BODY

text: delinquencies, charge-offs, and provisions. Banks should control and manage the volume and
label: BODY

text: complexity of workout programs including following regulatory reporting and GAAP
label: BODY

text: requirements. Banks should have an allowance for loan and lease losses (ALLL)
label: BODY

text: methodology that is consistent with GAAP and recognizes credit losses in a timely manner
label: BODY

text: through provisions and charge-offs.
label: BODY

text: Management should monitor and track the volume and performance of loans that have been
label: BODY

text: placed in workout arrangements and measure the effectiveness of programs over time (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: percentage of accounts that cure and charge off). The outcome should justify the practice. For
label: BODY

text: workout programs to be effective, banks may consider
label: BODY

text: • tracking the 13-month rolling volume of loans (number and dollar amounts) that were
label: BODY

text: placed into deferment, extension, forbearance, etc., by month and monitoring this long
label: BODY

text: term (e.g., last three years).
label: BODY

text: • monitoring performance for each deferment or forbearance since the deferment or
label: BODY

text: forbearance arrangement ended.
label: BODY

text: • tracking historical performance by repayment vintage and even grouping this by accounts
label: BODY

text: that received different types of workout since entering repayment.
label: BODY

text: • monitoring average credit score of accounts in forbearance or repayment (dollar
label: BODY

text: weighted) and comparing this with the average credit score for new volume.
label: BODY

text: Consolidation and Refinance
label: BODY

text: Some banks offer consolidation and refinance loans to borrowers who wish to simplify and
label: BODY

text: streamline their repayment efforts. Consolidation allows borrowers to combine private
label: BODY

text: student loans into single fixed-rate consolidation loans (or variable rate, if preferred), thus
label: BODY

text: providing single due dates and billing statements. If primary borrowers’ credit profiles have
label: BODY

text: improved significantly, the primary borrowers may qualify for better rates and may remove
label: BODY

text: the cosigners (if any) from individual loans. Consolidation and refinance may be used to
label: BODY

text: switch lenders and enable borrowers to shop for the best possible loan term and pricing.
label: BODY

text: Banks should exercise caution when offering consolidation of both federal and private
label: BODY

text: student loans. Borrowers who refinance federal student loans into private student loans may
label: BODY

text: lose favorable benefits from the original federal student loans (e.g., Perkins loan subsidized
label: BODY

text: interest and loan forgiveness). Banks may consider helping borrowers determine if
label: BODY

text: consolidation provides the expected benefit.
label: BODY

text: In general, both federal and private student loans cannot be discharged in bankruptcy. Still, in
label: BODY

text: determining whether student loans are protected against discharge (pursuant to
label: BODY

text: 11 USC 523(a)(8)(B)), banks should consider whether the loans meet the definition of
label: BODY

text: “qualified education loan.”71 The student loan debt should be incurred within “a reasonable
label: BODY

text: period”72 with the debt attributable to education furnished during a period in which the
label: BODY

text: borrowers were eligible students.
label: BODY

text: Recoveries
label: BODY

text: Recoveries are collection activities after accounts are charged off. Student loans are rarely
label: BODY

text: permitted to be discharged in bankruptcy, which allows lenders to pursue recoveries from
label: BODY

text: borrowers for longer periods if banks seek and obtain court judgments against borrowers.
label: BODY

text: 71 A bankruptcy discharge exception is applied to qualified education loans in 11 USC 523(a)(8)(B),
label: BODY

text: “Exceptions to Discharge.”
label: BODY

text: 72 The term “reasonable period” is defined in 26 CFR 1.221-1(e)(3)(ii), “Deduction for Interest Paid on
label: BODY

text: Qualified Education Loans After December 31, 2001.”
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Similar with other retail loan products, recovery activities for private student loans are
label: BODY

text: generally conducted internally and may be outsourced to collection agencies after several
label: BODY

text: months. Collection agencies receive a percentage of the dollars collected, and the percentage
label: BODY

text: varies based on whether the agency is the primary (the first agency to work the accounts),
label: BODY

text: secondary, or tertiary collector. The primary agency generally collects the lowest percentage,
label: BODY

text: and the tertiary agency collects the highest percentage.
label: BODY

text: Some of the factors that may affect the recovery rate are
label: BODY

text: • previous collection efforts.
label: BODY

text: • depth and experience of staff.
label: BODY

text: • adequacy of systems and controls.
label: BODY

text: • use of technology.
label: BODY

text: When the bank selects an agency with which the bank will outsource accounts, the bank
label: BODY

text: should perform appropriate due diligence to ensure that the agency is, among other things,
label: BODY

text: properly licensed and bonded. The bank should have systems to monitor the agency
label: BODY

text: continuously to ensure the agency is operating in a prudent manner. Bank management
label: BODY

text: should follow the guidance outlined in OCC Bulletin 2013-29, “Third-Party Relationships:
label: BODY

text: Risk Management Guidance,” as the bank works with third parties to collect accounts.
label: BODY

text: Allowance and Capital Treatment
label: BODY

text: For performing private student loans, bank management should establish appropriate ALLL
label: BODY

text: levels that consider the credit quality of the portfolios and conditions that affect
label: BODY

text: collectability. Most banks provide for at least one year of projected losses for their consumer
label: BODY

text: portfolios, though the coverage period may be shorter or longer based on portfolio
label: BODY

text: characteristics and performance. If the methodology and assumptions used are sound, the
label: BODY

text: analysis of the credit quality of the portfolios and conditions for collectability determines the
label: BODY

text: appropriate level and coverage of ALLL. Banks that engage in private student lending
label: BODY

text: activities must comply with the OCC’s risk-based capital and leverage ratio requirements that
label: BODY

text: apply to those activities.
label: BODY

text: All private student loans whose terms have been modified in a TDR should be evaluated for
label: BODY

text: impairment under Accounting Standards Codification Topic 310-10. Private student loans
label: BODY

text: that have been modified in a TDR are impaired when, based on analysis of current
label: BODY

text: information and events, it is probable that the bank will be unable to collect all amounts due
label: BODY

text: (i.e., both principal and interest) according to the contractual terms of the original loan
label: BODY

text: agreements. When the review of impaired private student loans confirms that a specific
label: BODY

text: restructured loan is uncollectable, the amount that is uncollectable should be charged off.
label: BODY

text: Banks with federal guaranteed student loan portfolios on their balance sheets should account
label: BODY

text: for the portion of the loans not covered by the guarantee in the banks’ ALLL and regulatory
label: BODY

text: capital. When government-guaranteed loans become 120 days past due, a dollar-for-dollar
label: BODY

text: reserve should be established for the unguaranteed portion and reported accurately for call
label: BODY

text: report and financial reporting purposes. For the purposes of capital, the guaranteed portion of
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: federal student loans is subject to a risk weight of 20 percent as a conditional guarantee of the
label: BODY

text: U.S. government while the remaining unguaranteed 0 percent to 3 percent should be risk
label: BODY

text: weighted at 100 percent. Private student loans that are 90 days past due have a general risk
label: BODY

text: weight of 150 percent.73
label: BODY

text: For more information on allowance, refer to OCC Bulletin 2006-47, “Allowance for Loan
label: BODY

text: and Lease Losses (ALLL): Guidance and Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) on the
label: BODY

text: ALLL,” and the OCC’s Bank Accounting Advisory Series.
label: BODY

text: Rehabilitated Federal Student Loans
label: BODY

text: Bank participation in the student lending industry is not simply confined to the “originate and
label: BODY

text: hold” model. In the past few years, some community banks found new opportunities by
label: BODY

text: purchasing pools (“buy and hold”) of student loans in the Federal Rehabilitation Student
label: BODY

text: Loan Program. The program is made up of federal student loans with borrowers who
label: BODY

text: previously defaulted but have brought the loans current with nine consecutive payments.
label: BODY

text: Federal student loans generally fall into default after borrowers miss 270 days of loan
label: BODY

text: payments (if payments are due monthly) or 330 days of loan payments (if payments are due
label: BODY

text: less frequently).74 The Education Department offers a federal student loan rehabilitation
label: BODY

text: program to help borrowers bring education loans out of default through affordable payments.
label: BODY

text: Rehabilitation is a one-time opportunity to remove a federal student loan default from a
label: BODY

text: borrower’s credit history and to regain student aid eligibility. To rehabilitate a federal student
label: BODY

text: loan, the borrower must make nine on-time,75 full monthly payments to the guarantor or its
label: BODY

text: contracted vendor during a period of 10 consecutive months. Payments must be made
label: BODY

text: voluntarily by the borrower and must be equal to or greater than the amount determined to be
label: BODY

text: reasonable and affordable. The definition of “voluntary” in this context excludes payments
label: BODY

text: made by garnishment or other offsets. After the borrower makes nine of 10 consecutive
label: BODY

text: payments and applies for and receives “rehabilitation,” the borrower will no longer be
label: BODY

text: considered in default.
label: BODY

text: A rehabilitated loan retains the same interest rate and deferment provisions that were
label: BODY

text: applicable when the loan was first disbursed and keeps repayment terms and all other
label: BODY

text: benefits applicable to other federal student loans. The borrower, however, regains eligibility
label: BODY

text: for deferment only to the extent that he or she has not already exhausted those deferment
label: BODY

text: privileges before the initial default. For example, a borrower who was initially eligible for
label: BODY

text: 24 months of unemployment deferment, and who used 12 months of that eligibility before his
label: BODY

text: or her default, would be eligible to defer the rehabilitated loan for only 12 months due to any
label: BODY

text: future unemployment status.
label: BODY

text: 73 Refer to 12 CFR 3, subpart D (12 CFR 3.30–3.63), “Risk-Weighted Assets–Standardized Approach.” The
label: BODY

text: OCC adopted the revised capital rules as final on July 9, 2013 (78 Fed. Reg. 62018 [October 11, 2013]).
label: BODY

text: 74 Refer to 34 CFR 682.200(b), “Definitions.”
label: BODY

text: 75 The term “on-time payment” is defined as payments within 20 days of the due date for FFELP and Direct
label: BODY

text: Loan Program loans and 15 days for Perkins loans.
label: BODY

text: Introduction > Risk Rating and Examiner Guidance
label: H4

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: Once loans are redeemed, they are removed from collections and either returned to the
label: BODY

text: original federal student loan servicers or purchased by eligible lending institutions.
label: BODY

text: Rehabilitation of FFELP loans usually requires that the loans be sold to lenders after the
label: BODY

text: borrowers complete the steps required to rehabilitate the loans. Community banks that buy
label: BODY

text: these pools of loans generally receive a 2 percent to 3 percent discount and use third parties
label: BODY

text: for servicing and administration. This new business is attractive to community banks because
label: BODY

text: the government guarantees 97 percent to 100 percent of the principal of each loan.
label: BODY

text: Rehabilitated FFELP loan pools are expected to have a higher net loss rate compared with
label: BODY

text: pools of non-rehabilitated FFELP loans because, although the rehabilitated loans benefit
label: BODY

text: from the same degree of federal guarantee, they are expected to default at a significantly
label: BODY

text: higher rate than non-rehabilitated loans. Bank management should ensure that the bank is
label: BODY

text: indemnified from any loan servicer errors and can adequately manage the risks, such as third-
label: BODY

text: party, liquidity, interest rate, compliance, and reputation risk.
label: BODY

text: Examiners should assess whether banks that buy these pools have a thorough understanding
label: BODY

text: of the risks associated with the portfolios. To most community banks, engaging in
label: BODY

text: rehabilitated FFELP is a new activity. Community bank examiners should closely monitor
label: BODY

text: how effectively banks manage this program.
label: BODY

text: This booklet contains expanded procedures for examining specialized activities or specific
label: BODY

text: products or services that warrant extra attention beyond the core assessment contained in the
label: BODY

text: “Community Bank Supervision,” “Large Bank Supervision,” and “Federal Branches and
label: BODY

text: Agencies Supervision” booklets of the Comptroller’s Handbook. Examiners determine which
label: BODY

text: expanded procedures to use, if any, during examination planning or after drawing
label: BODY

text: preliminary conclusions during the core assessment.
label: BODY

text: Scope
label: BODY

text: These procedures are designed to help examiners tailor the examination to each bank and
label: BODY

text: determine the scope of the student lending examination. This determination should consider
label: BODY

text: work performed by internal and external auditors and other independent risk control
label: BODY

text: functions and by other examiners on related areas. Examiners need to perform only those
label: BODY

text: objectives and steps that are relevant to the scope of the examination as determined by the
label: BODY

text: following objective. Seldom will every objective or step of the expanded procedures be
label: BODY

text: necessary.
label: BODY

text: The scope of student lending supervisory activities depends on the examiner’s knowledge of
label: BODY

text: those activities, the amount of total and product exposure, and the amount of risk posed to the
label: BODY

text: bank’s earnings and capital.
label: BODY

text: This booklet provides two sets of procedures: primary and supplemental.
label: BODY

text: The “Primary Examination Procedures” section in this booklet discusses the steps necessary
label: BODY

text: for a comprehensive student lending examination in smaller or less complex operations and
label: BODY

text: serves as the base student lending procedures for larger or more complex operations.
label: BODY

text: The “Supplemental Examination Procedures” section in this booklet discusses when
label: BODY

text: examiners should expand the scope of the examination. For example, it may be necessary to
label: BODY

text: supplement primary procedures when the bank offers new or significantly changed products,
label: BODY

text: when a particular concern exists, or when examining larger, more complex operations. The
label: BODY

text: supplemental examination procedures are grouped by functional areas. Examiners are
label: BODY

text: encouraged to refer to other Comptroller’s Handbook booklets, including the following:
label: BODY

text: • “Allowance for Loan and Lease Losses”
label: BODY

text: • “Community Bank Supervision”
label: BODY

text: • “Concentrations of Credit”
label: BODY

text: • “Internal and External Audits”
label: BODY

text: • “Internal Control”
label: BODY

text: • “Large Bank Supervision”
label: BODY

text: • “Loan Portfolio Management”
label: BODY

text: • “Rating Credit Risk”
label: BODY

text: Objective: To determine the scope of the examination of student lending and identify examination
label: BODY

text: objectives and activities necessary to meet the bank’s supervisory strategy needs.
label: BODY

text: 1. Review the following sources of information and note any previously identified problems
label: BODY

text: related to student lending that require follow-up:
label: BODY

text: • Supervisory strategy
label: BODY

text: • Examiner-in-charge’s (EIC) scope memorandum
label: BODY

text: • The OCC’s information system
label: BODY

text: • Previous reports of examination (ROE) and work papers
label: BODY

text: • Internal and external audit reports and work papers, including Education
label: BODY

text: Department’s lender servicer review report
label: BODY

text: • Bank management’s responses to previous ROEs and audit reports
label: BODY

text: • Borrower complaints and litigation
label: BODY

text: 2. Obtain the results of the Uniform Bank Performance Report and the OCC’s Canary
label: BODY

text: benchmark report.
label: BODY

text: 3. Obtain and review the policies, procedures, and reports bank management uses to
label: BODY

text: supervise student lending, including internal risk assessments.
label: BODY

text: 4. In discussions with bank management, determine if there have been any significant
label: BODY

text: changes (for example, in policies, processes, personnel, control systems, products,
label: BODY

text: volumes, markets, and geographies) since the previous examination of student lending.
label: BODY

text: 5. Based on an analysis of information obtained in the previous steps, as well as EIC input,
label: BODY

text: determine the scope and objectives of the student lending examination.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: EIC (refer to this booklet’s appendix B, “Sample Request Letter”).
label: BODY

text: 7. Select from the following primary and supplementary examination procedures the
label: BODY

text: necessary steps to meet examination objectives and the supervisory strategy.

text: Objective: To assess the quantity, quality, and sustainability of student lending earnings.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: planning and forecasting processes. Determine whether material changes are expected

text: in any of the key income and expense components and measures.

label: BODY

text: returns as of the examination date. Asset-based measures are typically more
label: BODY

text: meaningful for comparison because banks allocate capital differently.

text: recognition.

label: BODY

text: downturns.

text: 5. Determine whether the bank’s cost accounting system is capable of generating profit data
label: BODY

text: by product, segment (including grade), channel, and account.

label: BODY

text: show how efficiently management uses its assets to generate earnings. Return on assets is calculated by dividing
label: BODY

text: a bank’s annual earnings by its total assets.

text: Verification Procedures
label: BODY

text: Verification procedures are used to verify the existence of assets and liabilities, or test the
label: BODY

text: reliability of financial records. Examiners generally do not perform verification procedures as
label: BODY

text: part of a typical examination. Rather, verification procedures are performed when substantive
label: BODY

text: safety and soundness concerns are identified that are not mitigated by the bank’s risk
label: BODY

text: management systems and internal controls.
label: BODY

text: Objective: To verify the authenticity of the bank’s student loans and test the accuracy of records
label: BODY

text: and adequacy of record keeping.
label: BODY

text: Note: Examiners normally do not need to perform extensive verification. These procedures,
label: BODY

text: however, are appropriate when the bank has inadequate audit coverage of student lending
label: BODY

text: activities or when fraud or other irregularities are suspected.
label: BODY

text: 1. Test the additions of the trial balances and the reconciliation of the trial balances to the
label: BODY

text: general ledger. Include loan commitments and other contingent liabilities.
label: BODY

text: 2. After selecting loans from the trial balance by using an appropriate sampling technique
label: BODY

text: (refer to the “Sampling Methodologies” booklet of the Comptroller’s Handbook for
label: BODY

text: guidance on sampling techniques),
label: BODY

text: • prepare and mail confirmation forms to borrowers. (Loans serviced by other
label: BODY

text: institutions, either whole loans or participations, are usually confirmed only with the
label: BODY

text: servicing institution. Loans serviced for other institutions, either whole loans or
label: BODY

text: participations, should be confirmed with the buying institution and the borrower.
label: BODY

text: Confirmation forms should include borrower’s name, loan number, the original
label: BODY

text: amount, interest rate, current loan balance, and borrower status).
label: BODY

text: • after a reasonable time, mail second requests.
label: BODY

text: • follow up on any unanswered requests for verification or exceptions and resolve
label: BODY

text: differences.
label: BODY

text: • examine notes for completeness and compare agree date, amount, and terms with trial
label: BODY

text: balance.
label: BODY

text: • in the event notes are not held at the bank, request confirmation by the holder.
label: BODY

text: • check to see that required officer approvals are on the note.
label: BODY

text: • check to see that note is signed, appears to be genuine, and is negotiable.
label: BODY

text: 3. Review accounts with accrued interest by
label: BODY

text: • reviewing and testing procedures for accounting for accrued interest and for handling
label: BODY

text: adjustments.
label: BODY

text: • scanning accrued interest for any unusual entries and following up on any unusual
label: BODY

text: items by tracing them to initial and supporting records.
label: BODY

text: 4. Using a list of nonaccruing loans, check loan accrual records to determine that interest
label: BODY

text: income is not being recorded.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Appendix A: Transaction Testing
label: BODY

text: Overview
label: BODY

text: Examiners should perform testing procedures when the EIC determines that the OCC should
label: BODY

text: verify a bank’s compliance with its own policies and procedures or with regulatory policies,
label: BODY

text: regulations, or laws. The EIC institutes testing when deemed appropriate to assess the bank’s
label: BODY

text: risk selection, the accuracy of the bank’s MIS, or the accuracy of its loan accounting and
label: BODY

text: servicing. Testing procedures usually are performed periodically on student loan portfolios or
label: BODY

text: targeted segments of the portfolios, and when there is elevated risk (e.g., loans to students
label: BODY

text: attending for-profit schools), an increase in delinquency and loss rates, new student loan
label: BODY

text: programs, new acquisition channels, or rapid growth, or when loan review or audit is
label: BODY

text: inadequate.
label: BODY

text: Examiners conducting testing should be alert for potential discriminatory, unfair, deceptive,
label: BODY

text: abusive, or predatory lending practices (e.g., providing misleading disclosures). If
label: BODY

text: weaknesses are found or other concerns arise, consult the bank’s EIC or compliance
label: BODY

text: examiner.
label: BODY

text: These procedures recommend judgmental sample sizes. Sample sizes are suggestions only.
label: BODY

text: The sample size and targeted portfolio segment may be modified to fit the circumstances.
label: BODY

text: The sample selected should be sufficient in size to reach a supportable conclusion. Increase
label: BODY

text: the sample size if questions arise and more evidence is needed to support the conclusion.
label: BODY

text: Examiners may want to consider using a statistical sampling process for reaching conclusions
label: BODY

text: on an entire portfolio. Performing statistically valid transaction testing on portfolios of
label: BODY

text: homogeneous retail accounts is extremely effective. The benefits of statistical sampling allow
label: BODY

text: the examiner to quantify the results of transaction testing and state with a statistically valid
label: BODY

text: level of confidence that the results are reliable. For additional information, consult the
label: BODY

text: “Sampling Methodologies” booklet of the Comptroller’s Handbook.
label: BODY

text: Note: Appropriate sample size may vary based on the volume and complexity of the bank’s
label: BODY

text: private student lending activities.

text: Appendix D: Loss Forecasting Tool
label: BODY

text: Reliable forecasts of expected consumer charge-offs are critical for risk management,
label: BODY

text: profitability, reserving, and capitalization. This appendix describes the three most common
label: BODY

text: methods: roll rate models, historical averaging, and vintage-based forecasting. Some banks
label: BODY

text: use combinations of all three methods for different consumer portfolios or forecasting
label: BODY

text: purposes.
label: BODY

text: Roll Rates
label: BODY

text: Roll rate models are the most accurate short-term forecast technique. The name is derived
label: BODY

text: from the practice of measuring the percentage of delinquent loans that migrate or “roll” from
label: BODY

text: early delinquency to late-stage delinquency buckets, or to charge-off. The most common
label: BODY

text: method is the delinquency roll rate model, in which dollars outstanding are stratified by
label: BODY

text: delinquency status—typically, current, 30 to 59 days past due, 60 to 89 days past due, and so
label: BODY

text: on through charge-off. The rates at which loans migrate or roll through delinquency levels
label: BODY

text: are then used to project losses for the current portfolio. Figure 1 describes the mechanics of
label: BODY

text: using roll rate analysis to track the migration of balances over a four-month period (120-day
label: BODY

text: charge-off period).
label: BODY

text: Figure 1: Roll Rate Schematic
label: BODY

text: Step 1: Calculate roll rates
label: BODY

text: Step 1 is to calculate the roll rates. The following computation (figures 2 and 3) begins with
label: BODY

text: the $725 million in loans that were current in June 2014. From June 2014 to July 2014,
label: BODY

text: $27 million in loans migrated from current to 30 days delinquent, which equates to a roll rate
label: BODY

text: of 3.73 percent ($27 ÷ $725). From July 2014 to August 2014, $10.6 million rolled to the
label: BODY

text: next delinquency bucket, representing a 39.26 percent roll rate ($10.6 ÷ $27). Continuing
label: BODY

text: along the shaded, stair-stepped boxes in the following table, loss rates increase in the latter
label: BODY

text: stages of delinquency. To smooth out some fluctuations in the data, management often
label: BODY

text: averages roll rates by quarter before making current portfolio forecasts, and compares
label: BODY

text: quarterly roll rate results between quarters to analyze and adjust for seasonal effects.
label: BODY

text: The schematic and example in figures 2 and 3 are simplified depictions of dollar flow to
label: BODY

text: illustrate the basic concept of roll rates. In reality, some balances cure (return to current),
label: BODY

text: remain in the same delinquency bucket, or improve to a less severe delinquency status by the
label: BODY

text: end of a period. For ease of calculation, roll rate analysis assumes all dollars at the end of a
label: BODY

text: period flow from the previous period bucket.

text: Loss factors
label: BODY

text: Step 2: Calculate loss factors by bucket
label: BODY

text: Step 2 is to calculate loss factors for each bucket. To calculate the loss factor from the
label: BODY

text: “current” bucket, multiply all average roll rates from the most recent quarterly average. In
label: BODY

text: this example, the fourth quarter average roll rates produce this factor: 3.42% x 42.58% x
label: BODY

text: 67.12% x 72.12%, resulting in a 0.70 percent loss rate for loans in the current bucket. To
label: BODY

text: determine the loss rate for the 30-day accounts, multiply the most recent quarterly averages
label: BODY

text: for the 60-, 90-, and 120-day buckets, resulting in a loss factor of 20.61 percent. Applying the
label: BODY

text: same method results in a loss factor of 48.41 percent for the 60-day bucket and 72.12 percent
label: BODY

text: for the 90-day bucket.

text: Step 3 is to forecast losses for the existing portfolio by applying the loss factors for each
