label: BODY

text: The major advantage of roll rate analysis is its relative simplicity and considerable accuracy
label: BODY

text: out to nine months. Portfolios are often segmented by product, customer type, or other
label: BODY

text: relevant groupings to increase precision and accuracy. Collection managers use roll rate
label: BODY

text: reports extensively to anticipate workload and staffing needs and to assess and adjust
label: BODY

text: collection strategies.
label: BODY

text: The main limitation of roll rates is that the predictive power of delinquency roll rate declines
label: BODY

text: after nine months. The delinquency focus causes forecasts to lag underlying changes in
label: BODY

text: portfolio quality, especially in the relatively large current bucket. Portfolio quality changes
label: BODY

text: occur because of such factors as underwriting and cutoff score adjustments, product mix
label: BODY

text: changes, and shifts in economic conditions. Roll rate analysis may underestimate loss
label: BODY

text: exposure when these factors cause portfolio quality to weaken. Finally, roll rate methodology
label: BODY

text: assumes loans migrate through an orderly succession of delinquency stages before charge-
label: BODY

text: off. In actuality, customers often migrate to charge-off status after sporadic payments or rush
label: BODY

text: to that status by declaring bankruptcy.
label: BODY

text: Historical
label: BODY

text: Historical averaging is a rudimentary method for forecasting loss rates. Management tracks
label: BODY

text: historical charge-offs, adjusts for recent loss experience trends, and adds some qualitative
label: BODY

text: recognition of current economic conditions or changes in portfolio mix. This method is
label: BODY

text: highly judgmental and is used primarily by less sophisticated banks, or for stable,
label: BODY

text: conservatively underwritten products. The most common of these products are residential
label: BODY

text: mortgages when the collateral protection is conservative or the loans carry some sort of third-
label: BODY

text: party guaranty or insurance.
label: BODY

text: The method is sometimes used for allowance purposes and monitoring general product or
label: BODY

text: portfolio trends. The advantage is simplicity, and data needs are modest. Results can be
label: BODY

text: reasonably accurate as long as underwriting standards remain relatively constant and
label: BODY

text: economic or competitive conditions do not change markedly. The major limitation is that
label: BODY

text: forecasts will lag behind underlying changes in portfolio quality if competitive or economic
label: BODY

text: conditions change. The judgmental nature of the process introduces potential bias by
label: BODY

text: allowing forecasters to rely on longer run averages when conditions deteriorate and short-run
label: BODY

text: trends at the earliest signs of recovery, either of which results in lower loss estimates. In
label: BODY

text: addition, the method does not provide meaningful information on the effects of changes in
label: BODY

text: product or customer mix, and it is difficult to apply any but the most basic stress tests.
label: BODY

text: Vintage
label: BODY

text: Vintage-based forecasting tracks delinquency and loss curves by time on books as different
label: BODY

text: vintages or marketing campaign seasons. The patterns or curves are predictive for future
label: BODY

text: vintages, if adjustments are made for changes in underwriting criteria, altered cutoffs, and
label: BODY

text: Appendixes > Appendix D
label: BODY

text: Comptroller’s Handbook
label: BODY

text: Student Lending
label: HH1

text: economic conditions. The advantage of vintage-based forecasting is that its accuracy is
label: BODY

text: usually better than roll rate forecasts for charge-offs beyond a one-year horizon, if the need
label: BODY

text: for adjustments is readily observed. Management should adjust the future loss expectations
label: BODY

text: when new vintages are observed to deviate markedly from past curves and trajectories, or if
label: BODY

text: economic and market conditions change. The disadvantages of vintage-based forecasting are
label: BODY

text: that it is more subjective and less accurate than roll rates for short-term forecasting and that it
label: BODY

text: relies on the assumption that new vintages will perform similarly to older vintages.
label: BODY

text: Appendix E: Glossary
label: BODY

text: Note: Sources include the U.S. Department of Education, the Common Manual, and industry
label: BODY

text: websites, including FinAid.
label: BODY

text: Academic year: The period during which school is in session, consisting of at least 30 weeks
label: BODY

text: of instructional time. The academic year typically runs from approximately the beginning of
label: BODY

text: September through the end of May at most colleges and universities.
label: BODY

text: Allowance for loan and lease losses (ALLL): A valuation reserve that represents an
label: BODY

text: estimate of uncollectible amounts (probable and incurred losses) that is used to reduce the
label: BODY

text: book value of loans and leases to the amount that is expected to be collected. The allowance
label: BODY

text: is established and maintained by charges against the bank’s operating income, that is, the
label: BODY

text: provision expense.
label: BODY

text: Amortization: The process of gradually repaying a loan over a period of time through
label: BODY

text: periodic installments of principal and interest.
label: BODY

text: Award letter: An official document issued by a school’s financial aid office that lists all of
label: BODY

text: the financial aid awarded to the student.
label: BODY

text: Award year: The academic year for which financial aid is requested (or received). The
label: BODY

text: period from July 1 of a given calendar year through June 30 of the following calendar year.
label: BODY

text: Bankruptcy: Judicial action to stay the normal collection of debts against the petitioner and
label: BODY

text: cause those debts deemed to be satisfied at the direction of the court. Bankruptcies are
label: BODY

text: classified under the U.S. Code by “chapters,” which refer to parts of the U.S. Bankruptcy
label: BODY

text: Code.
label: BODY

text: Campus-based programs: The Federal Perkins Loan, Federal Work-Study, and Federal
label: BODY

text: Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant programs. These programs and their related
label: BODY

text: funds are administered directly by a school’s financial aid office. In return, the school is
label: BODY

text: allowed to retain a percentage of each program’s funds for its administrative costs. Awards
label: BODY

text: are made from a fixed pool of money.
label: BODY

text: Cancellation: Loan cancellation ends the obligation to repay the debt and typically involves
label: BODY

text: the discharge or forgiveness of the loan balance (including any accrued but unpaid interest).
label: BODY

text: Capitalization: The practice of adding unpaid interest charges to the principal balance of a
label: BODY

text: loan. Interest is then charged on the new balance, including both the unpaid principal and the
label: BODY

text: accrued interest.
label: BODY

text: Cohort default rate (CDR): The percentage of borrowers in the cohort who default on
label: BODY

text: certain loans made under federal student loan programs before the end of the second fiscal
label: BODY

text: year after the fiscal year in which they entered repayment on their loans. The Education
label: BODY

label: HH1

text: Department releases information on CDRs annually. For more information on the CDR and
label: BODY

text: how it is calculated, refer to the Education Department’s website.
label: BODY

text: Collection agency: A company often hired by the lender or guarantee agency to recover
label: BODY

text: defaulted loans.
label: BODY

text: Consolidation loan: Also called loan consolidation, a consolidation loan combines several
label: BODY

text: student loans into one larger loan from a single lender. The consolidation loan is like a
label: BODY

text: refinance and is used to pay off the balances on the other loans.
label: BODY

text: Cosigner: Any person who assumes personal liability, in any capacity, for the obligation of a
label: BODY

text: borrower without receiving goods, services, or money in return for the obligation. The
label: BODY

text: cosigner is equally and severally liable and is expected to make payments on the primary
label: BODY

text: borrower’s debt should that person default.
label: BODY

text: Cost of attendance: An estimate of the student’s educational expenses for the period of
label: BODY

text: enrollment.
label: BODY

text: Credit history: A credit history is a record of all events connected with payment of a set of
label: BODY

text: debts, such as on-time payments, late payments, nonpayment, default, liens, and bankruptcy
label: BODY

text: discharge. A credit history can include both current and previous credit accounts and their
label: BODY

text: balances, employment and personal information, and history of past credit problems.
label: BODY

text: Credit scoring: A statistical method for predicting the creditworthiness of applicants and
label: BODY

text: existing customers.
label: BODY

text: Default: A loan is in default when the borrower fails to pay several regular installments on
label: BODY

text: time or otherwise fails to meet the terms and conditions of the loan. A borrower who is
label: BODY

text: 120 days late on a private student loan or 270 days late on a federal education loan is
label: BODY

text: considered to be in default.
label: BODY

text: Default fee: Synonymous with guarantee fee. A guarantee is an agreement to purchase title
label: BODY

text: to a loan if the borrower defaults on his or her obligation to repay the debt.
label: BODY

text: Deferment: Occurs when a borrower is allowed to postpone repaying the loan.
label: BODY

text: Delinquent: A period that begins on the day after the due date of a payment when the
label: BODY

text: borrower fails to make a full payment.
label: BODY

text: Dependency status: A measure of the degree to which a student has access to his or her
label: BODY

text: parents’ financial resources.
label: BODY

text: Direct loans: The William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program (Direct Loan Program) is a
label: BODY

text: federal program in which the school becomes the lending agency and manages the funds
label: BODY

text: directly, with the federal government providing the loan funds. The terms for direct loans are
label: BODY

text: the same as for loans issued under the Stafford Loan program.

text: Direct Parental Loans for Undergraduate Students (Direct PLUS Loans): A federal
label: BODY

text: student loan available to graduate or professional degree students and parents of dependent
label: BODY

text: undergraduate students to help pay education expenses. Parents may borrow up to the full
label: BODY

text: cost of their children’s education, minus the amount of any other financial aid received.
label: BODY

text: Direct PLUS Loans may be used to pay the expected family contribution. There is a minimal
label: BODY

text: credit check required for the Direct PLUS loan.
label: BODY

text: Disbursement: The transfer of loan proceeds by individual check, master check, or
label: BODY

text: electronic funds transfer by a lender to a borrower, a school, or an escrow agent.
label: BODY

text: Discharge: The release of a borrower or any cosigner from all or a portion of his or her loan
label: BODY

text: obligation.
label: BODY

text: Disclosure statement: Provides the borrower with information about the actual cost of the
label: BODY

text: loan, including the interest rate, origination, insurance, loan fees, and any other types of
label: BODY

text: finance charges. Lenders are required to provide the borrower with a disclosure statement
label: BODY

text: before issuing a loan.
label: BODY

text: Electronic data exchange: Program used by participating schools to receive Student Aid
label: BODY

text: Reports electronically from the federal processor. At some schools, this program allows
label: BODY

text: students to file their FAFSA electronically.
label: BODY

text: Enrollment status: An indication of whether a student is attending school full time or part
label: BODY

text: time.
label: BODY

text: Entitlement: Entitlement programs award money to all qualified applicants. The Pell Grant
label: BODY

text: is an example of such a program. The Individuals With Disabilities Education Act Federal
label: BODY

text: Special Education Entitlement Grant is another example.
label: BODY

text: Expanded lending option: Under this option, some schools can offer higher annual and
label: BODY

text: cumulative loan limits to students receiving a Perkins Loan. The expanded lending option is
label: BODY

text: restricted to schools with a Perkins Loan default rate of 15 percent or less.
label: BODY

text: Expected family contribution (EFC): The amount a student and the student’s spouse or
label: BODY

text: family are expected to pay toward the student’s cost of attendance.
label: BODY

text: Federal Family Education Loan Program (FFELP): A discontinued student loan program
label: BODY

text: authorized by Title IV, part B, of the HEA, as amended. FFELP included subsidized and
label: BODY

text: unsubsidized Stafford, Direct PLUS, and consolidation loans. These loans were funded by
label: BODY

text: lenders, guaranteed by guarantors, and reinsured by the Education Department.
label: BODY

text: Federal methodology: The need analysis formula used to determine the EFC. The federal
label: H4

text: methodology takes into account the family size, the number of family members in college,
label: BODY

text: taxable and nontaxable income, and assets. Unlike most institutional methodologies, the
label: BODY

text: federal methodology does not consider the net value of the family residence.

text: Financial aid: Money provided to the student and the family to help them pay for the
label: BODY

text: student’s education, which is conditioned on the student’s attendance at an educational
label: BODY

text: institution. Major forms of financial aid include gift aid (grants and scholarships) and self-
label: BODY

text: help aid (loans and work).
label: BODY

text: Financial Aid Administrator: A staff member at an eligible school who administers
label: BODY

text: financial aid programs.
label: BODY

text: Financial Aid Office: The college or university office that is responsible for determining
label: BODY

text: financial need and awarding financial aid.
label: BODY

text: Financial aid package: The total amount of financial aid that a school awards a student.
label: BODY

text: Federal and nonfederal aid such as loans, grants, or work-study are combined into a
label: BODY

text: “package” to help meet the student’s cost of attendance. Using available resources to give
label: BODY

text: each student the best possible aid package is one of the major responsibilities of a school’s
label: BODY

text: financial aid administrator.
label: BODY

text: Financial aid transcript: An official record of the federal financial aid that a student
label: BODY

text: received at schools the student previously attended. The record is used to assess the amount
label: BODY

text: of federal financial aid the student has received and to prevent the award of federal funds for
label: BODY

text: which the student or the parent of a dependent student is not eligible. The record may be
label: BODY

text: obtained from the NSLDS or may be a paper report received from the previous schools.
label: BODY

text: Forbearance: A period of time during which the borrower is permitted to temporarily cease
label: BODY

text: making payments or reduce the amount of the payments for reasons including certain types
label: BODY

text: of financial hardships. The borrower is liable for the interest that accrues on the loan during
label: BODY

text: the forbearance period.
label: BODY

text: Forgiveness: Loan forgiveness releases the borrower from his or her obligation to repay the
label: BODY

text: loan, usually due to circumstances within the borrower’s control. For student loans, the most
label: BODY

text: common loan forgiveness programs cancel all or part of the debt for working in a particular
label: BODY

text: field or performing military or volunteer service. Loan forgiveness for working in a particular
label: BODY

text: occupation is tax-free; other types of loan forgiveness may result in a tax liability. There are
label: BODY

text: two main types of loan forgiveness: up-front and back-end. Up-front loan forgiveness cancels
label: BODY

text: a portion of the debt for each year of service. Back-end loan forgiveness cancels any
label: BODY

text: remaining debt after a specified number of years of service. Forgiveness is a type of loan
label: BODY

text: cancellation.
label: BODY

text: Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA): The form the student must complete
label: BODY

text: to apply for federal Title IV financial assistance, including Stafford Loans. The student must
label: BODY

text: include financial information about the student’s household so that the EFC can be
label: BODY

text: calculated.
label: BODY

text: Garnishment: The practice of withholding a portion of a defaulted borrower’s wages to
label: BODY

text: repay his or her loan, without consent.

text: Grace period: A time period after graduation during which the borrower is not required to
label: BODY

text: begin repaying his or her student loans. The grace period may also apply if the borrower
label: BODY

text: leaves school for a reason other than graduation or drops below half-time enrollment.
label: BODY

text: Depending on the type of loan, a borrower has a grace period of six months (Stafford Loans
label: BODY

text: and private student loans) or nine months (Perkins Loans) before the borrower must start
label: BODY

text: making payments. PLUS Loans do not have a grace period. CNBE Policy Guidance 2010-2
label: BODY

text: (REV), “Policy Interpretation: OCC Bulletin 2000-20—Application to Private Student
label: BODY

text: Lending,” allows a grace period of six months for private student loans, with an additional
label: BODY

text: six-month extended grace period if the borrower can document financial hardship.
label: BODY

text: Graduated repayment schedule: A repayment schedule under which the borrower pays
label: BODY

text: lower initial monthly payments that gradually increase (usually in two or more increments)
label: BODY

text: during the course of the repayment period. For federal student loans, the graduated
label: BODY

text: repayment schedule cannot exceed 10 years (or 25 years for borrowers eligible for an
label: BODY

text: extended repayment schedule), excluding in-school, grace, deferment, and forbearance
label: BODY

text: periods.
label: BODY

text: Grant: A type of financial aid based on financial need that the student does not have to
label: BODY

text: repay.
label: BODY

text: Guarantee: A guarantee is an agreement to purchase title to a loan if the borrower defaults
label: BODY

text: on his or her obligation to repay the debt.
label: BODY

text: Guarantee agency or guarantor: State agencies responsible for approving student loans
label: BODY

text: and insuring them against default. Guarantee agencies also oversee the student loan process
label: BODY

text: and enforce federal and state rules regarding student loans.
label: BODY

text: Guarantee fee: A small percentage of the loan that is paid to the guarantee agency to insure
label: BODY

text: the loan against default. The insurance fee is usually 1 percent of the loan amount. Also
label: BODY

text: known as a default fee.
label: BODY

text: Half time: An enrollment status under which a student in an undergraduate program is
label: BODY

text: carrying an academic workload that includes at least half of the academic workload of the
label: BODY

text: required minimum full-time enrollment standard for that program.
label: BODY

text: Income-Based Repayment Plan: A repayment plan available to a borrower who has a
label: BODY

text: partial financial hardship or is paying a permanent-standard payment amount after qualifying
label: BODY

text: for such a hardship. If a lender determines that a borrower has a partial hardship, the
label: BODY

text: borrower’s monthly payment amount on eligible loans is limited to 15 percent of the amount
label: BODY

text: by which the borrower’s annual adjusted gross income exceeds 150 percent of the U.S.
label: BODY

text: Department of Health and Human Services’ poverty guideline for the borrower’s family size.
label: BODY

text: The Education Department repays the outstanding balance and accrued interest on eligible
label: BODY

text: FFELP and direct loans after 25 years and a combination of 300 months covered by
label: BODY

text: qualifying payments or economic hardship deferments, beginning no earlier than July 1,

text: Income-Contingent Repayment Plan: A repayment schedule for some Direct Loan
label: BODY

text: Program loans under which the borrower’s monthly payment amount is adjusted annually,
label: BODY

text: based on the total amount of the borrower’s direct loans, the borrower’s family size, and the
label: BODY

text: adjusted gross income reported on the borrower’s most recent income tax return. In the case
label: BODY

text: of a married borrower who files a joint income tax return, the adjusted gross income includes
label: BODY

text: the spouse’s income.
label: BODY

text: Income-Sensitive Repayment Plan: A repayment schedule for some FFELP loans under
label: BODY

text: which the borrower’s monthly payment amount is adjusted annually, based solely on the
label: BODY

text: borrower’s expected total monthly gross income received from employment and other
label: BODY

text: sources during the course of the repayment period.
label: BODY

text: Independent student: An independent student is at least 24 years old as of January 1 of the
label: BODY

text: academic year, is married, is a graduate or professional student, has a legal dependent other
label: BODY

text: than a spouse, is a veteran of the U.S. Armed Forces, or is an orphan or ward of the court (or
label: BODY

text: was a ward of the court until age 18). A parent refusing to provide support for his or her
label: BODY

text: child’s education is not sufficient for the child to be declared independent.
label: BODY

text: Lender subsidies: A set of arrangements established to encourage lenders to make federally
label: BODY

text: guaranteed education loans. These arrangements include a federal guarantee against borrower
label: BODY

text: default, special allowance payments, and lender-paid origination fees.
label: BODY

text: LIBOR: The LIBOR, or London Interbank Offered Rate, is a variable rate index that
label: BODY

text: typically reflects the rates that financial institutions charge one another for short-term loans.
label: BODY

text: Loan servicer: A loan servicer is a business that collects payments on a loan and performs
label: BODY

text: other administrative tasks associated with maintaining a loan portfolio.
label: BODY

text: National credit bureau: A credit reporting agency with a service area encompassing more
label: BODY

text: than a single region of the country.
label: BODY

text: National Student Loan Data System (NSLDS): A database comprising information from
label: BODY

text: guarantors, schools, lenders, and the Education Department on Title IV aid received by
label: BODY

text: students.
label: BODY

text: Out-of-pocket cost: Out-of-pocket cost is the difference between the cost of attendance and
label: BODY

text: the grants, scholarships, and other gift aid in the need-based financial aid package. It reflects
label: BODY

text: the bottom line cost to the family, that is, the amount the family will need to pay out of
label: BODY

text: current and future resources, such as savings, income, and loans. Some nonprofit colleges
label: BODY

text: that have adopted no-loans financial aid policies have lower out-of-pocket costs than many
label: BODY

text: public colleges. Generally, families should evaluate college financial aid award letters using
label: BODY

text: out-of-pocket cost.
label: BODY

text: Out-of-state student: A student who has not met the legal residency requirements for the
label: BODY

text: state and is often charged a higher tuition rate at public colleges and universities in the state
label: BODY

text: than legal residents.

text: Overawards: A student who receives federal support may not receive awards totaling more
label: BODY

text: than $400 in excess of his or her financial need.
label: BODY

text: Packaging: The process of assembling a financial aid package.
label: BODY

text: Parent contribution: An estimate of the portion of educational expenses that the federal
label: BODY

text: government believes parents can afford. It is based on the parents’ income, the number of
label: BODY

text: parents earning income, assets, family size, the number of family members currently
label: BODY

text: attending a university or college, and other relevant factors. Students who qualify as
label: BODY

text: independent are not expected to have a parent contribution.
label: BODY

text: Participating school: An eligible school that meets the standards for participation in Title IV
label: BODY

text: programs, has a current program participation agreement with the Education Department, and
label: BODY

text: is eligible to receive funds under these programs.
label: BODY

text: Pell Grant: A federal grant that provides up to $5,815 (in 2016–2017) based on the student’s
label: BODY

text: financial need.
label: BODY

text: Perkins Loan: Formerly the National Direct Student Loan Program, the Perkins Loan allows
label: BODY

text: students to borrow up to $3,000 per year (up to a five-year maximum) for undergraduate
label: BODY

text: school and $5,000 per year for graduate school (up to a six-year maximum). The Perkins
label: BODY

text: Loan has one of the lowest interest rates and is awarded by the school’s financial aid
label: BODY

text: administrator to students with exceptional financial need. The student must have applied for a
label: BODY

text: Pell Grant to be eligible. The interest on the Perkins Loan is subsidized while the student is in
label: BODY

text: school.
label: BODY

text: Poverty line: The poverty guidelines, often referred to as the poverty line, are published
label: BODY

text: annually by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. The guidelines are a
label: BODY

text: simplification of the poverty thresholds published annually by the U.S. Census Bureau. The
label: BODY

text: poverty line is more often used in federal student aid, such as the Income-Based Repayment
label: BODY

text: and Income-Contingent Repayment plans, as well as the economic hardship deferment.
label: BODY

text: Preferred lender arrangement: An arrangement or agreement between a lender and a
label: BODY

text: school or an institution-affiliated organization under which the lender provides or otherwise
label: BODY

text: issues private education loans to students attending the school (or to the students’ families)
label: BODY

text: and under which the school or institution-affiliated organization recommends, promotes, or
label: BODY

text: endorses the lender’s education loan products.
label: BODY

text: Prime lending rate: The prime lending rate is the interest rate offered by lenders to their
label: BODY

text: best credit customers.
label: BODY

text: Private student loans: Education loan programs without a guarantee from the federal
label: BODY

text: government.
label: BODY

text: Professional degree: A degree that signifies both completion of the academic requirements
label: BODY

text: for beginning practice in a given profession and a level of professional skill beyond that

text: normally required for a bachelor’s degree. Professional licensure is also generally required.

text: requirements

text: required. The repayment period follows any applicable in-school or grace period.

text: Satisfactory academic progress: The qualitative (grade point average) and quantitative
label: BODY

text: (time limit) measures of a student’s progress toward completing a program of study. To
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: year.
label: BODY

text: Scholarship: A form of financial aid given to undergraduate students to help pay for their
label: BODY

text: education. Most scholarships are restricted to paying all or part of tuition expenses, though
label: BODY

text: some scholarships also cover room and board. Scholarships are a form of gift aid and do not
label: BODY

text: have to be repaid. Many scholarships are restricted to students in specific courses of study or
label: BODY

text: with academic, athletic, or artistic talent.
label: BODY

text: Skip tracing: Diligent efforts to locate a borrower’s telephone number or address when such
label: BODY

text: information is unknown.
label: BODY

text: Special allowance payments: Special allowance payments were established for FFELP to
label: BODY

text: ensure that education lenders received a market rate of return on federal education loans.

label: BODY

text: the Education Department would make special allowance payments to the lenders based on
label: BODY

text: the difference between the interest rates.
label: BODY

text: Stafford Loans: Federal student loans that come in two forms, subsidized and unsubsidized.
label: BODY

text: Subsidized loans are based on need, unsubsidized loans are not. The interest on a Subsidized
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Loans.
